=== [[Template talk:Infobox Indian state or territory#rfc_E859303|Template talk:Infobox Indian state or territory]] expired 2023-04-14 13:02 ===
* Id: E859303
* User: Haoreima
* Date: 2023-03-15 12:33:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|1144765543|TECH 1144765543}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1147566346|HIST 1147566346}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|1147566352|STYLE 1147566352}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1149791884|HIST 1149791884}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|1149791892|STYLE 1149791892}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|1149791896|TECH 1149791896}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
This template [[Template:Infobox Indian state or territory]] was created to replace the [[Template:Infobox settlement]] in all the articles of [[:Category:States and union territories of India]]. 
An editor [[User:Tojoroy20|Tojoroy20]] doesn't want the existence of the parameters "image_skyline", "imagesize", "image_alt" and "image_caption" in this template. Tojoroy assumes that those parameters aren't useful enough. On the other hand, [[User:Haoreima|Haoreima]] wants the existence of these parameters. According to Haoreima, before the creation of this particular template, all the articles on [[:Category:States and union territories of India]], used the [[Template:Infobox settlement]],  and all those articles utilize those particular parameters (whose existence is currently in conflict between these 2 editors), thereby considering it is logically reasonable to put them in the new template (this template) also, which is going to serve all those very articles. Wikipedians are welcome to comment whether to remove them or not. --[[User:Haoreima|Haoreima]] ([[User talk:Haoreima|talk]]) 12:33, 15 March 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Wikipedia Signpost#rfc_4D12436|Wikipedia talk:Wikipedia Signpost]] expired 2023-04-16 16:02 ===
* Id: 4D12436
* User: Onceinawhile
* Date: 2023-03-17 15:16:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/WikiProjects_and_collaborations|prev|1145160265|PROJ 1145160265}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/WikiProjects_and_collaborations|prev|1150151051|PROJ 1150151051}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
 Please comment on whether Signpost articles on open ArbCom cases should be NPOV, or whether one-sided opinion pieces are fine? The general question is sparked from the controversy around [[Wikipedia:Wikipedia Signpost/2023-03-09/Recent research|this Signpost article]], much of which can be seen at [[Wikipedia talk:Wikipedia Signpost/2023-03-09/Recent research|its talk page]]. In particular, see the WP:ANI thread [[Wikipedia:Administrators%27_noticeboard/IncidentArchive1122#Wikipedia:Wikipedia_Signpost/2023-03-09/Recent_research|here]], which was opened on the basis that the article {{tq|"prejudges an active Arbitration case"}}, suggested that the review prior to publication was {{tq|"the most ever for any Signpost piece"}} and was left up roughly on the basis that {{tq|"it is one editor's opinion. Not the voice of the SignPost"}}. 

So in an attempt to avoid similar chaos next time this happens, please provide your view on whether Signpost articles on open ArbCom cases should be written in an NPOV manner, or whether a one-sided opinion piece is fine. Ideally without commenting on the specifics of this one current ArbCom case. 

[[User:Onceinawhile|Onceinawhile]] ([[User talk:Onceinawhile|talk]]) 15:16, 17 March 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Requests for comment/Using maps as sources#rfc_ADD05EF|Wikipedia:Requests for comment/Using maps as sources]] expired 2023-04-18 06:11 ===
* Id: ADD05EF
* User: Moabdave
* Date: 2023-03-19 05:29:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1147250791|POLICY 1147250791}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1150441360|POLICY 1150441360}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Maps are used as references in [https://templatecount.toolforge.org/index.php?lang=en&namespace=10&name=Cite_map#bottom 32,000+ articles]. From time to time questions about their use are raised in venues such as [[WP:GAC]],[[WP:AFD]] and [[WT:OR]]. Policy and guidelines about sourcing and verifiability do not directly address nontextual sources. This RFC was started to answer some of those questions. I feel the Wikipedia community would benefit if we have some codified guidelines about their use to avoid having to continually revisit these topics.[[User:Moabdave|Dave]] ([[User talk:Moabdave|talk]]) 05:29, 19 March 2023 (UTC)}}

* Date: 2023-04-04 12:50:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1150325781|POLICY 1150325781}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1150452270|POLICY 1150452270}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
== Opinion polls '''

=== [[Wikipedia talk:No original research#rfc_17D33E4|Wikipedia talk:No original research]] expired 2023-04-18 23:06 ===
* Id: 17D33E4
* User: Elijahandskip
* Date: 2023-03-19 23:06:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1145592186|POLICY 1145592186}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1150579805|POLICY 1150579805}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
There has been disagreement between editors on multiple occasions whether or not the following situation is [[WP:OR|original research]] (not allowed) or if it falls under [[WP:CALC|basic and routine calculations]]:

Most tornadoes in the United States are given a damage total provided by the [[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration]] (NOAA). Based on the those damage totals, a list of the top ten costliest tornadoes of that year is created. An example would be [[Tornadoes of 2022#Costliest United States tornadoes]]. NOAA does not provide a straight list of the costliest tornadoes of the year. This means there is no explicit source saying what the top ten costliest tornadoes of the year are as it was derived from the provided damage totals. Are Wikipedia articles allowed to say X tornado was the (1st/2nd/3rd ect..) costliest tornado of the year under a basic and routine calculation (looking at which numbers are larger than other numbers) or does it fall under [[WP:OR|original research]] as no source explicitly states the list?

*'''Option 1''': It falls under [[WP:CALC]] as a basic and routine calculation.
*'''Option 2''': It falls under [[WP:OR|original research]] as no source explicitly states the list.
*'''Option 3''': Other - Should be described in detail by the editor.

[[User:Elijahandskip|Elijahandskip]] ([[User talk:Elijahandskip|talk]]) 23:06, 19 March 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard#rfc_7A2AF99|Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard]] expired 2023-04-20 13:04 ===
* Id: 7A2AF99
* User: Surveyor Mount
* Date: 2023-04-08 04:25:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1148890373|POLICY 1148890373}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1150849172|POLICY 1150849172}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Following these previous discussions from [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard/Archive 335#WION News]], and [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard/Archive 315#Is WION a reliable source?]], what is the reliability of [[WION]] ({{duses|wionnews.com}})?

*'''Option 1:''' Generally [[WP:RS|reliable]] for factual reporting
*'''Option 2:''' Unclear or additional considerations apply
*'''Option 3:''' Generally [[WP:QUESTIONABLE|unreliable]] for factual reporting
*'''Option 4:''' Publishes false or fabricated information, and should be [[WP:DEPS|deprecated]] as in the [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard/Archive 220#Daily Mail RfC|2017 RfC]] of the ''[[Daily Mail]]''?
<span style="font-family: Segoe Print;">[[User:Surveyor Mount|<span style="color: black">Surveyor</span>]]</span> <span style="font-family: Segoe Print;">'''[[User talk:Surveyor Mount|<span style="color: red">Mount</span>]]'''</span> 04:25, 8 April 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Gene Kelly#rfc_AC0BC6D|Talk:Gene Kelly]] expired 2023-04-23 17:05 ===
* Id: AC0BC6D
* User: Coretheapple
* Date: 2023-03-26 14:29:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1146717066|BIO 1146717066}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1146717069|SOC 1146717069}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1151374972|BIO 1151374972}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1151374976|SOC 1151374976}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Gene Kelly was a multitalented performer, but there is some dispute as to how he should be referred to in the opening of the article. I believe the choices are these:
* '''A'''  "actor, dancer, singer, filmmaker, and choreographer." This is the current formulation,
*  '''B''' "dancer, actor, singer, filmmaker and choreographer." 
The dispute is basically over whether to put "actor" or "dancer" first. I don't believe the order of the other two is at issue. [[User:Coretheapple|Coretheapple]] ([[User talk:Coretheapple|talk]]) 14:29, 26 March 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki#rfc_A3496BD|Talk:Atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki]] expired 2023-04-23 17:05 ===
* Id: A3496BD
* User: Binksternet

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)#rfc_A36C442|Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)]] expired 2023-04-24 04:03 ===
* Id: A36C442
* User: Cyclonebiskit
* Date: 2023-03-29 05:44:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|1147158797|SCI 1147158797}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|1147158800|STYLE 1147158800}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|1152099951|SCI 1152099951}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|1152099954|STYLE 1152099954}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Concern has been raised over the length and level of detail within individual tornado summaries. With direct access to the [https://apps.dat.noaa.gov/StormDamage/DamageViewer/ National Weather Service's Damage Assessment Toolkit], editors are able to obtain information on tornado impacts down to the street level. This also means the summaries are heavily reliant on a single source. We're mainly looking for guidance on how to best adhere to [[WP:MOS]] and [[WP:NOTEVERYTHING]] regarding what information is not insignificant and how detailed these prose summaries should be. The primary section prompting this discussion is [[Tornado outbreak of March 24–27, 2023#Rolling Fork–Midnight–Silver City, Mississippi]] but this same concern extends to many other tornado articles (including but not limited to [[2011 Joplin tornado]], [[2021 Western Kentucky tornado]], and [[Tornado outbreak of December 10–11, 2021]]). ~ [[User:Cyclonebiskit|Cyclonebiskit]] ([[User talk:Cyclonebiskit|chat]]) 05:44, 29 March 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Man#rfc_6892C32|Talk:Man]] expired 2023-04-25 23:01 ===
* Id: 6892C32
* User: Born25121642
* Date: 2023-03-26 22:20:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|1146783278|SCI 1146783278}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1146783281|SOC 1146783281}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|1151735985|SCI 1151735985}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1151735990|SOC 1151735990}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the lede sentence of [[Man]], ''"A man is an adult male human",'' include a footnote saying that male may refer to sex or gender? 

As it is now, some readers may read "male" as sex, and others may read "male" as gender, which may result in confusion. So, some options are:

* '''A''' - Keep it as it is: "A man is an [[adult]] [[male]] [[human]]."
* '''B''' - Add a footnote saying "''Male'' may refer to sex or gender."
* '''C''' - Add a footnote saying "''Male'' in this case meaning belonging to the sex which typically produces sperm, or to the gender which is typically associated with it." (using the [[wikt:male#English|wiktionary definition]])
* '''Other''' - suggest another idea if you think something else could work.

We can of course add references to the statement, like from Merriam Webster, OED, and Cambridge English Dictionary if needed. [[User:Born25121642|Born25121642]] ([[User talk:Born25121642|talk]]) 22:20, 26 March 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Scott Adams#rfc_71A2024|Talk:Scott Adams]] expired 2023-04-27 23:01 ===
* Id: 71A2024
* User: NickCT
* Date: 2023-03-29 03:07:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1147695925|BIO 1147695925}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1147695929|POL 1147695929}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1147695932|SOC 1147695932}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1152059447|BIO 1152059447}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1152059450|POL 1152059450}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1152059451|SOC 1152059451}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
There's been a debate about how to describe recent controversial remarks about race from cartoonist Scott Adams. The debate centers around whether his comments should be described as "racist" in a narrative/Wikipedia voice, or whether the adjective should be attributed.

Should the desription in lead read as either;

<u>Option A</u> : "...after Adams published a video which included ''racist comments about Black people.''"

'''or'''

<u>Option B</u> : "...after Adams published a video which included ''comments about Black people that were widely characterized as racist.''"

'''or'''

<u>ALT1</u> <small>(as proposed by [[User:DFlhb|DFlhb]])</small> "...after ''he characterized Black Americans as a "hate group"''"

'''or'''

<u>ALT2</u> <small>(as proposed by [[User:Rhododendrites|Rhododendrites]])</small> "...after ''he characterized Black Americans as a "hate group" and said that white people should "get the hell away from Black people"''"

Please tell us what you think below! If you could format your response in the following way, it would be helpful.

*'''Support Option A''' 
*'''Support Option B''' 
*'''Support Alternative'''

Thanks in advance for your input. [[User:NickCT|NickCT]] ([[User talk:NickCT|talk]]) 03:07, 29 March 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)#rfc_DE11713|Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)]] expired 2023-04-28 06:01 ===
* Id: DE11713
* User: Worm That Turned
* Date: 2023-04-17 14:05:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1150332494|POLICY 1150332494}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1155298821|POLICY 1155298821}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Although rare, there are situations where the community has consensus that an administrator should be blocked indefinitely, or at least for a significant period. In those circumstances, this proposal suggests that administrators who have been blocked for more than 28 days do not hold the trust of the community and therefore the sysop userright should be removed procedurally alongside [[WP:INACTIVITY|inactivity desysops]]. [[User:Worm That Turned|<b style="color:#000;">''Worm''</b>]]<sup>TT</sup>([[User talk:Worm That Turned|<b style="color:#060;">talk</b>]]) 14:05, 17 April 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard#rfc_A2313D0|Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard]] expired 2023-04-28 09:01 ===
* Id: A2313D0
* User: Doug Weller
* Date: 2023-03-29 08:44:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|1147176620|PROP 1147176620}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|1152116238|PROP 1152116238}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
 
We use this website in a number of articles.[https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?search=irishcentral.com&title=Special%3ASearch&ns0=1&ns1=1&ns2=1&ns3=1&ns4=1&ns5=1&ns14=1&ns15=1&ns100=1&ns101=1]. Its own article was deleted via [[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/IrishCentral]]. My latest encounter with this was at [https://www.irishcentral.com/roots/history/dna-ancient-egyptians-ireland?fbclid=IwAR3IOwz7BzuEm7w67RFuI_VYBtkDAwrYd6HdXkrulrpA3DQp0GBrtSz1o6M] where it uses a reliable source to push the idea of Egyptians in Ireland by using it alongside a fringe video. I think at best this should be classified generally unreliable. [[User:Doug Weller|<span style="color:#070">Doug Weller</span>]] [[User talk:Doug Weller|talk]] 08:44, 29 March 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Elizabeth Holmes#rfc_28E374E|Talk:Elizabeth Holmes]] expired 2023-04-28 18:01 ===
* Id: 28E374E
* User: Bdushaw
* Date: 2023-04-18 05:31:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1150502186|BIO 1150502186}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Economy,_trade,_and_companies|prev|1150502189|ECON 1150502189}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1152179863|BIO 1152179863}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Economy,_trade,_and_companies|prev|1152179865|ECON 1152179865}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Is the use of the label "fraudster" for Holmes appropriate, in the lead or otherwise?  There is guidance on [[MOS:LABEL]] and [[WP:BLPSTYLE]] on the use of labels applied to people in biographies, but they appear to me to be not definitive in the present case.  It's clear the use of labels is an issue of concern for Wikipedia, and a biography of a living person demands special care.  Further, the issue extends beyond the present article to others, e.g., [[Sunny Balwani]] and likely many other articles (and perhaps similar labels).  It's also clear that sometimes, though a label for a person is formally correct, it is not employed for an article, out of decorum or other reasons.  Use of the "fraudster" label in reliable sources is ambiguous, some sources use the term, others don't. '''N.B.''' This RFC is specifically limited to the use of the ''label'' "fraudster", or equivalent.  There is universal consensus that Holmes' fraud is to be stated early in the lead. [[User:Bdushaw|Bdushaw]] ([[User talk:Bdushaw|talk]]) 05:31, 18 April 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Scott Adams#rfc_8F24A95|Talk:Scott Adams]] expired 2023-04-29 18:01 ===
* Id: 8F24A95
* User: Floquenbeam
* Date: 2023-03-30 17:44:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1147147849|BIO 1147147849}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1147147853|POL 1147147853}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1147147854|SOC 1147147854}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1152348660|BIO 1152348660}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1152348662|POL 1152348662}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1152348665|SOC 1152348665}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
There has been a prolonged debate about the validity of the wording {{tq|the [[Anti-Defamation League]] said the seemingly innocuous phrase began being used online in 2017 as part of an [[alt-right]] trolling campaign and is associated with the [[white supremacist]] movement}} versus {{tq|according to the [[Anti-Defamation League]], a non-governmental organization, the phrase originated online in 2017 as part of an "[[alt-right]] trolling campaign" and as such is associated with the [[white supremacist]] movement}} to describe the phrase ''It's okay to be White'' in the context of this article. The debate, insofar as it has actually taken place, centers around whether wording such as "seemingly innocuous" to describe a political slogan should be written in Wikipedia's voice or attributed to its origin.

Should the desription in lead read as either;

<u>Option A</u> : "... the [[Anti-Defamation League]] said the seemingly innocuous phrase began being used online in 2017 as part of an [[alt-right]] trolling campaign and is associated with the [[white supremacist]] movement."

'''or'''

<u>Option B</u> : "... according to the [[Anti-Defamation League]], <s>a non-governmental organization</s> <small>[attempting to salvage the RFC by boldly removing this, as this is not what discussion is actually about, and no one seems to want it.  revert if you disagree. --[[User:Floquenbeam|Floquenbeam]] ([[User talk:Floquenbeam|talk]])]</small>, the phrase originated online in 2017 as part of an "[[alt-right]] trolling campaign" and as such is associated with the [[white supremacist]] movement."


Please tell us what you think below! If you could format your response in the following way, it would be helpful.

*'''Support Option A''' - This option is great [[User:Unqualified123|Unqualified123]] ([[User talk:Unqualified123|talk]]) 
*'''Support Option B''' - I love qualifying stuff. [[User:QualifyIt|QualifyIt]] ([[User talk:QualifyIt|talk]]) 
*'''Support Alternative''' - Why not attribute the existing prose? [[User:ThinkOutsideTheBox|ThinkOutsideTheBox]] ([[User talk:ThinkOutsideTheBox|talk]]) 

Thanks in advance for your input. [[User:Fishing Publication|Fishing Publication]] ([[User talk:Fishing Publication|talk]]) 17:44, 30 March 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:New Zealand#rfc_1B88396|Talk:New Zealand]] expired 2023-04-30 00:03 ===
* Id: 1B88396
* User: KlayCax
* Date: 2023-03-30 23:17:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1147440196|HIST 1147440196}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Language_and_linguistics|prev|1147440199|LANG 1147440199}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1147440202|POL 1147440202}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1147440206|SOC 1147440206}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1152392737|HIST 1152392737}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Language_and_linguistics|prev|1152392739|LANG 1152392739}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1152392745|POL 1152392745}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1152392751|SOC 1152392751}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
 

There is a presently a debate on whether New Zealand's article should include mention of the country's official status as a major non-NATO ally of the United States and identification with the core [[Anglosphere]]. 

* Should New Zealand's status as a [[major Non-NATO ally]] of the United States be mentioned, as is done in other articles? (e.g. [[Argentina]], [[Brazil]], [[Philippines]], [[Tunisia]], ''et al.'') 
* Should New Zealand's status as a member of the [[Anglosphere]] be mentioned in the article? (Along with mention of Māori culture + growing multiculturalism) 
* What version is better? [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=New%20Zealand&oldid=1147432983 Version #1]? (Which ''includes'' mention) Or [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=New%20Zealand&oldid=1147433172 version #2]? (Which ''excludes'' mention) 

Thanks. [[User:KlayCax|KlayCax]] ([[User talk:KlayCax|talk]]) 23:17, 30 March 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard#rfc_F2DF3DD|Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard]] expired 2023-04-30 16:01 ===
* Id: F2DF3DD
* User: Yae4
* Date: 2023-04-04 19:16:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|1148217409|SCI 1148217409}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1148217413|POL 1148217413}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1148217417|SOC 1148217417}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|1152496729|SCI 1152496729}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1152496732|POL 1152496732}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1152496736|SOC 1152496736}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Which of the following best describes PrivacyTools.io or PrivacyGuides.org technology articles?

* Option 1: Generally reliable
* Option 2: Additional considerations apply
* Option 3: Generally unreliable

Disclaimer: I may have previously cited either or both of these. Mea Culpa.
Summary: '''Option 3: Generally unreliable''' for both.
Background: As far as I know, neither website has been discussed here previously, but PrivacyTools was previously mentioned (by me) to support a different source. Privacy Guides is a "fork" of Privacy Tools circa 2021. There was [[Wikipedia:Articles_for_deletion/PrivacyTools]] in 2019, result: Delete. Oddities: The PrivacyTools article creator, [[User:UnnamedUser]], was blocked for puppetry. The only Keep came from [[User:JonahAragon]], who requested Draft restore in 2021 [[Special:Diff/926083267]], and has recently worked on [[Draft:Privacy Guides]] (with declared COI). They also cited Privacy Guides to add critical comparative statements (negative towards CalyxOS) to [[CalyxOS]] and [[GrapheneOS]], and cited or mentioned PrivacyTools or PrivacyGuides elsewhere: [[Special:Diff/1146474677]], [[Special:Diff/1146473478]]. Privacytools.io has been cited a few times[https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?search=insource%3Aprivacytools.io&title=Special%3ASearch&ns0=1]. Summary: Both websites are group (or individual) blogs (and advocacy sites) without evidence of editorial oversight, and as such are unreliable. -- [[User:Yae4|Yae4]] ([[User talk:Yae4|talk]]) 19:16, 4 April 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:April Fools#rfc_6BF6AB5|Wikipedia talk:April Fools]] expired 2023-05-02 01:02 ===
* Id: 6BF6AB5
* User: 73.168.5.183
* Date: 2023-04-02 00:15:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1147762547|POLICY 1147762547}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1152121338|POLICY 1152121338}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
There are usually [[WP:BLP]] issues with joke AfD of living people, and usually those end up being deleted later, in [[WP:MfD]]. For example, this year, a user started a [[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/Kanye West (2nd nomination)|joke AfD for Kanye West]], and then later the joke AfD was nominated for deletion [[Wikipedia:Miscellany for deletion/Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/Kanye West (2nd nomination)|here]]. There have been previous joke AfDs that have been deleted in the past, such as a joke AfD for Donald Trump, which resulted in [[Wikipedia:Miscellany for deletion/Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/Donald Trump (3rd nomination)|a serious MfD here]]. Thus, I propose joke AfD of living people to be banned. [[Special:Contributions/73.168.5.183|73.168.5.183]] ([[User talk:73.168.5.183|talk]]) 00:15, 2 April 2023 (UTC)}}

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
[[User:Wesoree]] got banned by [[User:GeneralNotability]] for pranking [[User:Oshwah]]'s user page. However, there is no rule on [[Wikipedia:Rules for Fools]] that states that people cannot prank other people's user pages. I propose that pranking other users' user pages be formally banned. [[Special:Contributions/73.168.5.183|73.168.5.183]] ([[User talk:73.168.5.183|talk]]) 00:06, 2 April 2023 (UTC)}}

{{rfcquote|text=
Which type of infobox should be used for the last two general elections in Italy (held under a new voting system introduced in 2017)?

# an {{tl|Infobox election}} (see by way of example [[Talk:2022 Italian general election/Draft Rfc#Option A|Option A]] or [[Talk:2022 Italian general election/Draft Rfc#Option B|Option B]]);
# an {{tl|Infobox legislative election}} (see by way of example [[Talk:2022 Italian general election/Draft Rfc#Option C|Option C]] or [[Talk:2022 Italian general election/Draft Rfc#Option D|Option D]]);
# a mixed infobox (the status quo, see [[Talk:2022 Italian general election/Draft Rfc#Option E|Option E]]).

Each user is requested to express the order of his preferences (not just the preferred option), <u>in order to facilitate the achievement of consensus</u>.

Please do not respond to other editors in the Survey. You may respond to other editors in the Discussion section. --[[User:Scia Della Cometa|Scia Della Cometa]] ([[User talk:Scia Della Cometa|talk]]) 19:39, 3 April 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Love jihad#rfc_3EDC0A5|Talk:Love jihad]] expired 2023-05-04 18:02 ===
* Id: 3EDC0A5
* Date: 2023-05-03 04:44:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1152929810|POL 1152929810}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|1152938987|RELI 1152938987}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1153181785|POL 1153181785}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|1153181786|RELI 1153181786}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
A new section with the title, "Instances" should be created and these instances should be mentioned in this article:-
:{{Tq|* One Aftab Poonawala murdered his Hindu girlfriend, Shraddha Walkar, cut her dead body into pieces and disposed of the parts in different parts of Delhi.<ref name="Pandey 2022">{{cite web | last=Pandey | first=Geeta | title=Shraddha Walkar and Aftab Poonawala: India gripped by gruesome 'fridge murder' | website=BBC News | date=25 November 2022 | url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-india-63739683 | access-date=19 December 2022}}</ref> In his statement to the Delhi police he said that he had absolutely no regrets about what he had done and he would be rewarded in “jannah” with 72 “hoors” smelling of [[Islamic State|ISIS]] indoctrination.<ref name="IndyaTv News 2022">{{cite web | title=Shraddha Walkar murder case: Aftab Poonawalla had extensively read ISIS and Al Qaeda propaganda material | website=IndyaTv News | date=4 December 2022 | url=https://news.indyatv.in/breaking/shraddha-walkar-murder-case-aftab-poonawalla-had-extensively-read-isis-and-al-qaeda-propaganda-material/ | access-date=19 December 2022}}</ref>}}
:{{Tq|* A Hindu girl was chopped into pieces by her supposed lover, a Muslim.<ref name="Khokon 2022">{{cite web | last=Khokon | first=Sahidul Hasan | title=As Shraddha murder shocks India, Hindu girl chopped into pieces by lover in Bangladesh | website=India Today | date=18 November 2022 | url=https://www.indiatoday.in/world/story/as-shraddha-murder-shocks-india-hindu-girl-chopped-into-pieces-by-lover-in-bangladesh-2298779-2022-11-18 | access-date=26 April 2023}}</ref>}}
:{{Tq|* A tribal Christian girl was chopped into pieces by her Muslim lover.<ref name="Sharma 2022">{{cite web | last=Sharma | first=Nootan | title='Love-jihad' has a new territory. With Jharkhand murder, it has entered the tribal belt | website=ThePrint | date=27 December 2022 | url=https://theprint.in/features/love-jihad-has-a-new-territory-with-jharkhand-murder-it-has-entered-the-tribal-belt/1284488/ | access-date=26 April 2023}}</ref>}}
:{{Tq|* A Muslim man was arrested for murdering his Hindu wife in Mumbai and her kin claim it to be love jihad.<ref name="Ali 2023">{{cite web | last=Ali | first=Ahmed | title=Man held for killing wife in Mumbai; her kin allege 'love jihad' - Mumbai News | website=The Times of India | date=9 January 2023 | url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/mumbai/man-held-for-killing-wife-in-mumbai-her-kin-allege-love-jihad/articleshow/96841451.cms | access-date=26 April 2023}}</ref>}}
:{{Tq| }}<br>
:{{Tq|The [[Vishwa Hindu Parishad]] released a list of four hundred cases and demanded a law against it by the Government of India.<ref name="Neelam 2022">{{cite web | last=Pandey | first=Neelam | title=VHP releases list of 400 ‘love Jihad’ cases, demands central law from Modi govt | website=ThePrint | date=1 December 2022 | url=https://theprint.in/india/vhp-releases-list-of-400-love-jihad-cases-demands-central-law-from-modi-govt/1244141/ | access-date=26 April 2023}}</ref>}}
:The term, "Islamophobic conspiracy theory" must be removed from the lead.
:<br>A subsection to the, "Instances" section should be added with the title, "In popular culture and the movie, "[[The Kerala Story]]" should be mentioned with a sentence or two about the movie with a link about the Wikipedia article about it.-04:44, 3 May 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Triangular trade#rfc_BBB439A|Talk:Triangular trade]] expired 2023-05-06 02:03 ===
* Id: BBB439A
* User: Uruiamme
* Date: 2023-04-06 00:14:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Economy,_trade,_and_companies|prev|1148417244|ECON 1148417244}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1148417250|HIST 1148417250}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Economy,_trade,_and_companies|prev|1153393784|ECON 1153393784}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1153393787|HIST 1153393787}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
There are two opposing sides to whether a triangular trade existed in colonial times, roughly between 1500 and 1850. On one side, there is the belief that ships would visit three separate areas and trade in a cyclical, clockwise path around the Atlantic Ocean. This would usually include three of these general locations: Western Europe, Western Africa, Eastern South America, the Islands of the Caribbean, Central America, and the Eastern North America. Slaves from Africa would always be included in this triangular trade. And if Europe was visited, North America was not, and vice versa. Images on this page show two common triangular trade routes.

The opposing belief is that slave ships were not able to easily convert to the shipment of raw or manufactured goods, being made almost exclusively for human cargo. Additionally, sailing times and other issues hampered the ability to conduct one circuit in a calendar year. The other argument is that triangular trade was a ''theory'' put forth in the 19th century, but was found difficult to support. This belief essentially says that trade was ''more commonly'' or ''almost exclusively'' bi-lateral, and that gold and silver would have been traded for the slaves rather than a bulk commodity like wood, sugar, or tobacco. Furthermore, triangular trade has few modern, reliable sources supporting it. The triangular trade is said to be a notion that ''introductory ''or ''elementary'' textbooks would teach, and even though the end result was similar to a triangular trade, ''the basic premise is oversimplified (at its least) and false (at its worst)''. This belief would agree to all of the shipping lines shown in triangular trade maps, but that ships were not sailing three of them in a circuit.

This RfC is intended to encompass the debate of the existence of the page, or at least the way it presents the topic as if it was a well-researched overview of the way the [[Atlantic slave trade]] was conducted. I also note that this page seems to be a restatement of the trading portion of the [[Atlantic slave trade]] article, with both articles using notions that largely connect them to one another. If the opposing view is correct, then the article needs to carefully explain that the notion of a triangular trade has limits, or be considered for deletion. However, as another commenter has stated on this page (see ''Caveat?''), it seems to be a trope in history books to refer to triangular Atlantic trade routes, even if its historical basis is tenuous. That makes it a notable topic that would not need deletion, even if determined by consensus to be unhistorical. [[User:Uruiamme|I like to saw logs!]] ([[User talk:Uruiamme|talk]]) 00:14, 6 April 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject United States#rfc_9753DD8|Wikipedia talk:WikiProject United States]] expired 2023-05-07 04:02 ===
* Id: 9753DD8
* User: KlayCax
* Date: 2023-04-07 03:06:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1148594239|HIST 1148594239}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1148594242|POL 1148594242}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1148594244|SOC 1148594244}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1153569219|HIST 1153569219}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1153569223|POL 1153569223}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1153569225|SOC 1153569225}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
 
This is a massively complicated RFC that can't be distilled into a simple "yes" or no question. So I'm breaking it down into five main questions. 

# Should the subject of abortion ever be mentioned in any state article's political section? (Outside of historical information surrounding abortion.) 
# If #1 is "yes", should information about state's abortion laws be included in every state's body? (Provided that the information from [[WP: RS]] on present law is ''available'', ''verifiable'', and ''clear''.) 
# Should U.S. states that are ''exceptional'' in abortion law have that mentioned in their respective ''leads''? (Either through the criteria I suggested ''or'' an alternative method.) 
# If #3 is "yes", is the criteria I proposed for #3 to determine what is "exceptional" in the "my proposal" section reasonable and should be used as policy going forward? 
# (Optional) Is there any other suggestions/et al. that you want to add? 
[[User:KlayCax|KlayCax]] ([[User talk:KlayCax|talk]]) 03:06, 7 April 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:S.U.C.C.E.S.S.#rfc_9603A03|Talk:S.U.C.C.E.S.S.]] expired 2023-05-07 18:02 ===
* Id: 9603A03
* User: Aufumy
* Date: 2023-04-07 17:57:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1148687376|POL 1148687376}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1148687379|SOC 1148687379}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1153680723|POL 1153680723}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1153680725|SOC 1153680725}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I had asked for a 3rd opinion, but the answer seemed neutral. Amigao has one point of view, and I have another point of view, and we each don't seem to want to budge.

This is the current version of Amigao's paragraph; 
<blockquote>As of 2015, SUCCESS was listed as an "Overseas Chinese Services Organization" by the Overseas Chinese Affairs Office (OCAO), at the time part of the State Council of the People's Republic of China.[9][10][11] In 2018, OCAO was absorbed by the Chinese Communist Party's United Front Work Department.[11]</blockquote>

My main point is that being mentioned on a foreign government website, does not make you a government organization. Also the Chinese characters used to designate a government office were different than what they listed SUCCESS under. Other countries government websites also list ethnic organizations in Canada, does not make every ethnic organization in Canada a foreign government run entity.

Since Amigao insists on suggesting that SUCCESS is a Chinese government office, with constant references to OCAO and the history of OCAO, and undoes any change, I tried to expand on both our points of view with a new subsection, shown https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=S.U.C.C.E.S.S.&oldid=1148603227#Controversy_of_the_affiliation_of_SUCCESS_to_the_Chinese_government

But Amigao keeps undoing everything, with the current explanation that it is too much of an essay.

My main question is: Is there proof that SUCCESS is a Chinese government office?

[[User:Aufumy|Aufumy]] ([[User talk:Aufumy|talk]]) 17:57, 7 April 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Naming conventions (writing systems)#rfc_A1DCC37|Wikipedia talk:Naming conventions (writing systems)]] expired 2023-05-08 05:03 ===
* Id: A1DCC37
* User: .Raven#Script vs alphabet]] and [[User talk:Kwamikagami#"Script" in article titles]]. Please note [https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/alphabet Merriam-Webster's definition 1(a) of "alphabet": "a set of letters or other characters with which '''''<u>one or more</u>''''' languages are written especially if arranged in a customary order"] (emphasis added again). &ndash;&nbsp;[[User:.Raven
* Date: 2023-04-08 04:39:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1148763885|POLICY 1148763885}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1153760689|POLICY 1153760689}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
 Should "alphabet" in [[WP:NCWS]] include letter-sets for specific uses (e.g. [[ISO basic Latin alphabet]], [[International Phonetic Alphabet]], [[Theban alphabet]]), as well as for specific languages (e.g. Somali's [[Kaddare alphabet]] and [[Osmanya alphabet]]; Zaghawa's [[Zaghawa alphabet]]; Mandaic's [[Mandaic alphabet]])?
Background: per Vanisaac's comment opening [[WT:NCWS#Honing in on a consensus]], "I think we are seeing an emerging consensus on 'X script' for all of the scripts out there, eg 'Latin script', ' 'Phags Pa script', 'Jurchen script'; and 'X alphabet' for national alphabets, notation systems, and other symbol collections for specific languages '''''<u>or use</u>''''', eg 'Belarusian Latin Alphabet', 'NATO phonetic alphabet', 'Russian alphabet' (implied Cyrillic), 'American manual alphabet', etc. The plural forms 'X scripts' and 'X alphabets' should be used for describing a family of scripts, and the collection of script conventions for writing a given language or in a particular medium, eg. 'Brahmic scripts', 'Semitic scripts', 'Belarusian alphabets', 'Semaphore alphabets', 'Manual alphabets{{'"}} (''"or use"'' emphasis added by me).

The text later placed by a different editor, without consensus, omitted the "or use:" alternative: {{"'}}Alphabet' is used for '''''<u>language-specific</u>''''' adaptations of a segmental script, usually with a defined sorting order and sometimes with not all of the letters, or with additional letters" (emphasis added again). That same editor has since cited his own text to insist that the ISO basic Latin alphabet, the IPA, and Theban, which can be used by multiple languages, are therefore not "alphabets", but "scripts". As this aspect of the "convention" was not consensus – his draft received two comments, one disagreeing, one not clearly either supporting or opposing – it's a one-person "rule" with no moral force in my opinion. I reverted to reinstate the prior version and add "or use-specific" per the consensus mentioned above: {{"'}}Alphabet' is used for specific applications of a segmental script, usually with a defined sorting order and '''''<u>sometimes with language-specific or use-specific</u>''''' letters" (emphasis added; the text other than "or use-specific" is from the prior version). He reverted my reversion. At this point I decline to edit-war, and instead post this RfC.

Lengthy foregoing discussion at [[Talk:Theban script#Requested move 3 April 2023]] and [[WT:NCWS]], as well as side-discussions at [[User talk:.Raven#Script vs alphabet]] and [[User talk:Kwamikagami#"Script" in article titles]]. Please note [https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/alphabet Merriam-Webster's definition 1(a) of "alphabet": "a set of letters or other characters with which '''''<u>one or more</u>''''' languages are written especially if arranged in a customary order"] (emphasis added again). &ndash;&nbsp;[[User:.Raven|<sub>'''•'''</sub>Raven]]&nbsp;<sup>[[User talk:.Raven|&nbsp;'''''.'''talk'']]</sup> 04:39, 8 April 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Naming conventions (royalty and nobility)#rfc_7165F19|Wikipedia talk:Naming conventions (royalty and nobility)]] expired 2023-05-10 02:06 ===
* Id: 7165F19
* User: Estar8806
* Date: 2023-04-10 01:35:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1149078089|BIO 1149078089}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|1149078096|STYLE 1149078096}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1149078098|POLICY 1149078098}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1154070689|BIO 1154070689}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|1154070695|STYLE 1154070695}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1154070703|POLICY 1154070703}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
It's been two months since I last proposed an RfC on this matter and I've come to realize that I may have formed that RfC poorly. So I'm going to give it a second go (note- I apologize if this is against any policy that I'm aware of)

So, to my question: should the article titles for deceased princesses who received a title from marriage (such as [[Princess Louise, Duchess of Argyll]] in the UK) have their article titles based on:

'''A''' - The title they held at birth, in line with [[WP:CONSORTS]] for the spouses of sovereigns; or (for example: the example I cited above would be moved to [[Princess Louise of the United Kingdom]];<br/>
'''B''' - The highest title they held during their lifetimes (where the example I've used her would remain at the present title).<br/>
'''C''' - whatever [[WP:COMMONNAME]] dictates. (added by [[User:Johnbod|Johnbod]])

I understand that some have a problem with seeking consistency where it may not exist in the 'real world'. However, [[WP:CONSISTENT]] is a part of our article titles policy. Even if we don't always abide by it (perhaps not nearly as much as we should, but I digress) we should at least have some form of guideline to abide by if/when consistency is needed. Happy to hear everyone's thoughts, [[User:Estar8806|Estar8806]] ([[User talk:Estar8806|talk]]) 01:35, 10 April 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)#rfc_B3F86A5|Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)]] expired 2023-05-10 18:02 ===
* Id: B3F86A5
* User: CandyScythe
* Date: 2023-05-06 10:25:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1153442048|POLICY 1153442048}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1154168313|POLICY 1154168313}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should full-size Creative Commons NC, ND, or NCND, or compatible, licensed files be allowed?

'''Context'''

Some files are classified as non-free by Wikipedia standards but are available under a license that permits educational, personal, or otherwise non-commercial use and/or prohibits derivative works. These include certain Creative Commons licenses.

The [[WP:NFCCP|policy]], as currently written, has a number of criteria that must be met in order for a non-free file to be used. One of these is the minimal extent of use which is further specified as "including usage of low-resolution, rather than high-resolution/fidelity/bit rate (especially where the original could be used for deliberate copyright infringement)". Bots enforce this provision by automatically resizing any files deemed too large.

The [[:wmf:Resolution:Licensing policy]] is the ultimate authority in copyright matters. It authorizes projects to develop and adopt an Exemption Doctrine Policy consistent with the resolution, permitting "the upload of copyrighted materials that can be legally used in the context of the project". The proposed change is fully compatible with the resolution.

This proposal was discussed before [[Wikipedia talk:Non-free content#Non-free licensed images| here]].

'''Rationale'''

Low-resolution requirement is in the policy solely because fair use compliance so requires. It is intended to reduce the reusability of the file, and so any adverse commercial impact our use would cause to the copyright holder. However, under these licenses, no fair use considerations are required.

We should always use free files when available, and this change would in no way affect that requirement. However, when we are given the option to either use the file under a claim of fair use and reduce its quality, or use it under a non-free license, we should choose the less bad alternative. To do otherwise would be a disservice to both our readers and re-users. 

It would also better respect the wishes of the copyright holders: they want (and in case of ND explicitly require) us (and the general public) to use their works in their original form, but we are in fact forcibly altering them to a worse quality. I don't think we can even claim our use to be fair if, given the option to use unaltered files, we choose to alter it anyway and misrepresent its quality.

Best, [[User:CandyScythe|CandyScythe]] ([[User talk:CandyScythe|talk]]) 10:25, 6 May 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:2023 Covenant School shooting#rfc_F52DE22|Talk:2023 Covenant School shooting]] expired 2023-05-10 23:01 ===
* Id: F52DE22
* User: FormalDude
* Date: 2023-04-10 22:50:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1149227927|BIO 1149227927}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1149227933|HIST 1149227933}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1149227940|POL 1149227940}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1149227944|SOC 1149227944}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1154204200|BIO 1154204200}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1154204205|HIST 1154204205}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1154204208|POL 1154204208}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1154204213|SOC 1154204213}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
 
How should the perpetrator be named in the article?<br>
'''A.''' "Aiden Hale" only<br>
'''B.''' Use both "Aiden Hale" and "Audrey Elizabeth Hale" 

If B, how often should "Audrey Elizabeth Hale" be mentioned?<br>
'''C.''' Once (please specify where)<br>
'''D.''' More than once (please specify where)

Background: The article is (at the time of this RfC) under full protection, and mentions "Audrey Elizabeth Hale" once, in the perpetrator section. Other mentions of the perpetrator (in the lead and infobox) say "Aiden Hale". 

Discussions that lead to this RfC: {{slink|#Full_protection?}} • {{slink|#Removal_of_birth_name_Audrey_Elizabeth_Hale}} • {{slink|#Deadname}}.<br> ––[[User:FormalDude|<span style="color:#004ac0">Formal</span><span style="color:black">Dude</span>]] [[User talk:FormalDude|<span style="color:#004ac0;font-size:90%;">(talk)</span>]] 22:50, 10 April 2023 (UTC)}}

The below subsection on African American culture has been suggested for inclusion and was removed. === [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard#rfc_6E794F1|Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard]] expired 2023-05-11 18:02 ===
* Id: 6E794F1
* User: Yae4
* Date: 2023-04-11 17:45:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|1149352932|SCI 1149352932}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1149352942|POL 1149352942}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1149352946|SOC 1149352946}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|1154321711|SCI 1154321711}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1154321716|POL 1154321716}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1154321722|SOC 1154321722}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Which of the following best describes [[Tweakers]].net articles?

* Option 1: Generally reliable
* Option 2: Additional considerations apply
* Option 3: Generally unreliable

AFAIK [[Tweakers]].net has not been discussed here. It has been cited a lot.[https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?search=insource%3Atweakers.net&title=Special%3ASearch&ns0=1] Concern was expressed here: [[Draft_talk:Privacy_Guides]], but the declared COI editor and I did not agree. Although Tweakers site lists editors and appears to have editorial staff, I found a article like this[https://tweakers.net/nieuws/186818/privacytools-punt-io-verandert-naam-wegens-afwezigheid-oprichter.html] to be troubling because it was submitted by a person with obvious COI, and that person was extensively quoted; it was cited in [[Draft:Privacy_Guides]]. Without extensive review of the website, to me it appears similar to Reddit, or a large group blog. -- [[User:Yae4|Yae4]] ([[User talk:Yae4|talk]]) 17:45, 11 April 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Atomic de Broglie microscope#rfc_02F265A|Talk:Atomic de Broglie microscope]] expired 2023-05-11 20:02 ===
* Id: 02F265A
* User: Johnjbarton
* Date: 2023-05-11 00:32:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|1154223252|SCI 1154223252}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|1154335748|SCI 1154335748}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The page is speculation and redundant links AFAICT.

No citation or information in the describes a "de Broglie" microscope. The picture in the page is for an atomic force microscope, a version of a scanning tunneling microscope, unrelated to a matter wave based microscope.

On the other hand, the page has a lot of redundant content from [[Quantum reflection]]

There do exist microscopes fitting the category, 

Koch, Markus, et al. "Imaging with neutral atoms—a new matter‐wave microscope." Journal of microscopy 229.1 (2008): 1-5.

I used this reference in [[Matter wave]] but I removed the link from Matter wave to this page.

IMO the current page would need to be almost completely replaced to be correct. 

"Matter wave microscope" would be an appropriate title. De Broglie said nothing on this subject.

Advice? My specific proposal:
 1) verify that all valuable content is in fact on other pages.
 2) remove the last link to this page
 3) delete
 4) create a new page under an appropriate title if and when resources/ physics progress suggest it.

[[User:Johnjbarton|Johnjbarton]] ([[User talk:Johnjbarton|talk]]) [[User:Johnjbarton|Johnjbarton]] ([[User talk:Johnjbarton|talk]]) 00:32, 11 May 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Timothée Chalamet#rfc_4A58755|Talk:Timothée Chalamet]] expired 2023-05-12 20:04 ===
* Id: 4A58755
* User: Hatrant
* Date: 2023-04-12 20:02:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1149537163|BIO 1149537163}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1154481682|BIO 1154481682}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
How should Timothée Chalamet's nationality be described in the lead and short description?

*'''A''') Lead: {{tq|Timothée Hal Chalamet is a French-American actor.}} Shortdesc: {{tq|French-American actor (born 1995)}}
*'''B''') Lead: {{tq|Timothée Hal Chalamet is an American actor.}} Shortdesc: {{tq|American actor (born 1995)}}
This RFC aims to discuss whether Timothée Chalamet's current mention as an "American actor" on Wikipedia accurately reflects his identity. Some argue that Chalamet's French heritage, bilingual upbringing, and references to French culture in his work and through his father and sister suggest that he should be referred to as a "French-American actor" instead. Others argue that he was born and raised in the United States and should be referred to as an "American actor". The RFC invites input from all users to determine the most accurate way to describe Chalamet's nationality on Wikipedia. [[User:Hatrant|Hatrant]] ([[User talk:Hatrant|talk]]) 20:02, 12 April 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)#rfc_BA99B39|Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)]] expired 2023-05-15 08:01 ===
* Id: BA99B39
* User: CX Zoom
* Date: 2023-04-15 07:42:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|1149920538|TECH 1149920538}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|1154882667|TECH 1154882667}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
As we know the new default skin Vector-2022 has a "Clear the watchlist" option on the main watchlist screen beside "Edit raw watchlist" option. Personally, I get scared by its existence here, I have a habit of misclicks and I have 3000+ pages in the watchlist. I can't afford to lose it all. This option may also cause some confusion to non-native English users: "Clear the watchlist" might also mean that the current watchlist screen is cleaned, and not all the pages of watchlist. And ofcourse this is not as widely used an option to merit inclusion right on front of the watchlist screen. People don't put pages on their watchlist only to perform a mass removal 2 days later. This option can safely be moved away from the main page and only inside the edit watchlist pages. This RfC is to determine whether there is consensus among the community to seek such a technical change to the new watchlist. <span class="nowrap">&#8212;'''[[User:CX Zoom|CX Zoom]]'''[he/him]</span> <sup class="nowrap">([[User talk:CX Zoom|let's talk]] • {[[Special:Contributions/CX Zoom|C]]•[[User:CX Zoom/X|X]]})</sup> 07:42, 15 April 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)#rfc_3F1FB10|Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)]] expired 2023-05-17 15:03 ===
* Id: 3F1FB10
* Date: 2023-05-06 18:46:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1153494679|BIO 1153494679}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1158713067|BIO 1158713067}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
This RFC covers 3 questions pertaining to the treatment of deceased trans or nonbinary persons' deadnames.
#What name should articles ''principally'' use to refer to a deceased trans or nonbinary person?
#When should Wikipedia articles include the former name of a deceased trans or nonbinary person ''who was not notable prior to transitioning''?
#How often should Wikipedia articles mention a deceased trans persons former name?
--<span style="font-family:Georgia">'''[[User:Jerome Frank Disciple|Jerome Frank Disciple]]'''</span> 18:46, 6 May 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Colleen Ballinger#rfc_D9E369B|Talk:Colleen Ballinger]] expired 2023-05-17 19:02 ===
* Id: D9E369B
* User: Songwaters
* Date: 2023-04-26 19:19:00

{{rfcquote|text=
Should an infobox be added to this article? [[User:Songwaters|Songwaters]] ([[User talk:Songwaters|talk]]) 19:19, 26 April 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:George of Imotski#rfc_E3CDD8F|Talk:George of Imotski]] expired 2023-05-18 00:06 ===
* Id: E3CDD8F
* User: Governor Sheng
* Date: 2023-05-17 21:40:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1155374752|BIO 1155374752}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1155374754|HIST 1155374754}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Language_and_linguistics|prev|1155374758|LANG 1155374758}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1155374765|POLICY 1155374765}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1155393375|BIO 1155393375}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1155393380|HIST 1155393380}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Language_and_linguistics|prev|1155393383|LANG 1155393383}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1155393389|POLICY 1155393389}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Since the English-language literature is lacking, and the literature, in general, is lacking, what article title should I use for a non-English person?

George of Imotski is referred to in the literature, which is mostly in the Croatian language as "[https://scholar.google.com/scholar?hl=en&as_sdt=0%2C5&q=%22Juraj+Imo%C4%87anin%22&btnG= Juraj Imoćanin]" (literally meaning Juraj from Imotski), and in the Latin-language literature, he is referred to simply as "Georgius". The literature on this bishop is ''very lacking'', both in Croatian and Latin, while in English it is practically non-existent. The same situation is with [[Jerome of Trogir]] (who is referred to as "Jeronim Trogiranin" in Croatian, and in Latin as "[https://scholar.google.com/scholar?hl=en&as_sdt=0%2C5&q=%22hieronymus+de+Tragurio%22&btnG= Hieronymus de Tragurio]"), [[Nicholas of Zadar]] (who is referred to as "[https://scholar.google.com/scholar?hl=en&as_sdt=0%2C5&q=%22Nikola+Zadranin%22&btnG= Nikola Zadranin]" in Croatian, and in Latin as "Nicolaus de Iadera") te [[Vid of Hvar]] (who is referred to as "[https://scholar.google.com/scholar?hl=en&as_sdt=0%2C5&q=%22Vid+Hvaranin%22&btnG= Vid Hvaranin]" in Croatian, and in Latin as "[https://scholar.google.com/scholar?hl=en&as_sdt=0%2C5&q=%22Vitus+de+Ruschis%22&btnG= Vitus de Ruschis]".

Per [[WP:COMMONNAME]], Wikipedia generally prefers the name that is most commonly used (as determined by its prevalence in a significant majority of independent, reliable ''English-language'' sources. The issue is, there are no English-language sources, only Croatian-language or Latin-language sources.

Per [[WP:UE]], the choice between anglicised and local spellings should follow English-language usage. Here, the issue is the same as explained above, due to the lack of English-language sources.

The same rule continues: "If there are too few reliable English-language sources to constitute an established usage, follow the conventions of the language appropriate to the subject." Does this mean the articles should be renamed to "Juraj Imoćanin", "Jeronim Trogiranin", "Nikola Zadranin" and "Vid Hvaranin". If so, should I use Croatian or Latin conventions?

The issue is complicated further, because, the rule continues: "For lesser known geographical objects or structures with few reliable English sources, follow the translation convention". Does this apply to people as well?

Then, this advice is given to help resolve the issue: "For ideas on how to deal with situations where there are several competing foreign terms, see "Multiple local names" and "Use modern names" in the ''geographical'' naming guideline. Such discussions can benefit from '''''outside opinions''''' so as to avoid a struggle over which language to follow." This is hardly applicable to this situation and I'm in real need of an outside opinion.

The rule then adds this: "In deciding whether and how to translate a foreign name into English, ''follow English-language usage''. If there is ''no established English-language treatment for a name, '''translate''' it if this can be done without loss of accuracy and with greater understanding for the English-speaking reader''." If this is the path I should take, have the translations been done correctly?

The opinions of other editors will help me with naming other similar existing articles I recently created (and mentioned here). Thank you all in advance. [[User:Governor Sheng|Governor Sheng]] ([[User talk:Governor Sheng|talk]]) 21:40, 17 May 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:What Wikipedia is not#rfc_785AC16|Wikipedia talk:What Wikipedia is not]] expired 2023-05-18 19:01 ===
* Id: 785AC16
* User: Evelyn Marie
* Date: 2023-05-15 10:16:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1154897836|POLICY 1154897836}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1155567806|POLICY 1155567806}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
<s>It is clear that the vast majority of editors want to see the policy stay; however how about clarification? This policy does not, within its current meaning, say that articles bound by the policy, e.g. version history articles, are outright banned. It says to use common sense on the amount of detail to include, and only states ''exaustiveness'', e.g. listing comprehensive release notes for every little change, but major feature highlights and version summarizations (e.g. as seen on [[Fedora Linux release history]] and [[Ubuntu version history]]) should not run afoul of this. So, instead of removing the policy outright (which after having thought about it is indeed a bad idea as it could result in more copyvio happening), how about clarifying the policy to allow highlights of major features and version summarizations directly, while disallowing comprehensive detail such as change-by-change release notes? The previous RFC specifically focused on removal, and clarification wasn't really discussed, so it might be better to have a second RFC. This is what I personally had in mind:

'''Current wording'''
:{{green|'''Exhaustive logs of software updates''' Use reliable third-party (not self-published or official) sources in articles dealing with software updates to describe the versions listed or discussed in the article. Common sense must be applied regarding the level of detail to include.}}

'''Suggested'''
:{{green|'''Exhaustive logs of software updates'''. Use reliable third-party (not self-published or official) sources in articles dealing with software updates to describe the versions listed or discussed in the article. Common sense must be applied regarding the level of detail to include; e.g. comprehensive release notes of individual software versions should be excluded, while major feature highlights and version summarizations should follow the policy on reliable third-party sourcing.}}

With changes of course to perhaps improve wording and remove unnecessary word duplication. But the policy in its current state is open to vast misinterpretation, and has been misinterpreted to turn ''exhaustiveness'' into saying that version history articles are straight up not allowed. So I am seeking opinions and debate on whether or not this policy should be clarified. - [[User:Evelyn Marie|Evelyn Marie]] ([[User_talk:Evelyn Marie|leave a message]] · [[Special:Contributions/Evelyn Marie|contributions]]) 10:16, 15 May 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)#rfc_EC9A5B7|Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)]] expired 2023-05-18 21:01 ===
* Id: EC9A5B7

** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1155538505|POLICY 1155538505}}

=== [[Talk:Scientific racism#rfc_97B3AF6|Talk:Scientific racism]] expired 2023-05-19 17:02 ===
* Id: 97B3AF6
* User: JBradleyChen
* Date: 2023-05-19 13:57:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1155741917|HIST 1155741917}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1155774929|HIST 1155774929}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I would appreciate feedback on [[User:JBradleyChen/sandbox|my proposed edit]] to the article on [[Scientific racism]], on the inclusion of Thomas Malthus in any form, and on the general editorial approach for this page. 

My proposed edit can be found in [[User:JBradleyChen/sandbox|my sandbox]]. I have not submitted it as an edit to the article as I was hoping to achieve consensus in the [[Talk:Scientific racism#Thomas Malthus|Talk page]] first. [[User:JBradleyChen/sandbox|My current text]] represents multiple compromises I made in deference to feedback from editors:

* that a featured quote from Malthus was too long (05:52, 8 May 2023). I replaced it with a summary.
* opposition to my quote from Chase 1977 identifying Malthus as “the founding father of scientific racism.” (00:58, 7 May 2023) I omitted that quote.
* opposition that my proposed edit was “single sourced” from Chase 1977. I de-emphasized Chase and added arguments based on chattel slavery, Social Darwinism and Eugenics, each with multiple sources exclusive of Chase.

I believe these edits have improved the article, and am grateful for the feedback, but it is unclear to me at this point if other editors were interested in improving my contribution, or were simply opposed to including anything about Malthus at all (17:51, 12 May 2023). They also object to my current draft based on WP:SYNTH. My draft documents the influence of Malthus on Scientific racism, with sources that support his influence on chattel slavery, Social Darwinism, and Eugenics.  The editors assert that the association of Malthus with Scientific racism depends on WP:SYNTH via intermediate concepts of chattel slavery, Social Darwinism and Eugenics. My position is that chattel slavery, Social Darwinism, and Eugenics are racism, hence SYNTH is not required, and also that [[Wikipedia:What SYNTH is not#SYNTH is not a rigid rule|SYNTH is not a rigid rule]]. Note I do not claim that Malthus was racist, only that he influenced Scientific racism.

This RfC should probably focus on Thomas Malthus, but if reviewers are inclined I would also welcome more general input on this article. My proposed edit is also a compromise. Earlier, [[Talk:Scientific racism#Recognizing Egalitarian Contributions|I commented]] that the Scientific racism page as written is very negative, and tends to demean competent scientists like Linnaeus and Rush and Darwin who argued for egalitarianism in their time. Rush and Darwin were also active opponents of slavery, hard to discern from this article. The article as structured makes it hard for a reader to recognize the trajectory of major themes in Scientific racism, such as polygenism, Social Darwinism and Eugenics. Instead it anchors on the immature science and decontextualized racism of pre-modern scholars. Meanwhile it ignores figures such as Malthus, Herbert Spencer, Lewis Terman and William Shockley, whose impact on Social Darwinism and Eugenics is well documented. While I don’t understand the overall editorial strategy, I do understand tactically why it’s been hard for me to include Malthus: the editors’ readiness to litigate technical details, making consensus on change difficult. [[User:JBradleyChen|JBradleyChen]] ([[User talk:JBradleyChen|talk]]) 13:57, 19 May 2023 (UTC)}}

Should the lede of the article describe ''The Grayzone'' as "a conspiracy theory website", "a fake news website", neither, or both? <b style="font-family:Trebuchet MS">[[User:Vanilla Wizard|<b style="background-color:#07d;color:#FFF">&nbsp;Vanilla </b>]][[User Talk:Vanilla Wizard|<b style="background-color:#749;color:#FFF">&nbsp;Wizard </b>]]</b> [[Special:Contribs/Vanilla Wizard|💙]] 20:01, 19 April 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Society for Evidence-Based Gender Medicine#rfc_42664CB|Talk:Society for Evidence-Based Gender Medicine]] expired 2023-05-19 23:01 ===
* Id: 42664CB
* User: Colaheed777
* Date: 2023-05-19 20:28:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1155813078|SOC 1155813078}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1155830764|SOC 1155830764}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I intend to promote this article to the "Good article status", as it is an important topic and we should cover it thoroughly. I started researching it a few weeks ago and discovered some additional coverage which we can use to expand the article. To get an impartial opinion, I'm starting this RfC:

The lead paragraph of this article is mainly supported by citations from publications such as: ''[[The Advocate (magazine)|The Advocate]]'', ''[[Medscape]]'', ''Clinical Practice in Pediatric Psychology'', Yale report, and Trans Safety Network. However, upon closer examination, the accuracy and reliability of these sources come into question. 

1. ''The Medscape'' citation fails [[WP:V]] standards as I couldn't verify the statement. 

2. ''The Clinical Practice in Pediatric Psychology'' has since retracted its quoted statement, rendering it invalid ([https://psycnet.apa.org/doiLanding?doi=10.1037%2Fcpp0000482 retracted link]). I'm, therefore, removing this statement.

3. ''The Advocate'''s is merely a brief mention of SEGM and its inclusion in the lead is undue. The characterization of SEGM as a "biased group" or "not a recognized scientific association" is also contestable due to the newspaper's natural bias and should be attributed.

4. An article from ''[[Science-Based Medicine]]'' (its Wikipedia page describes it as a "blog"), is authored by AJ Eckert, a [https://anchorhealthct.org/providers/aj-eckert/ trans doctor]. As a result, their viewpoint may be subject to potential bias. This statement is undue in the lead and should be attributed within the "Reception section".

5. A referenced report from Yale should be considered with caution, as it is explicitly noted that "[https://medicine.yale.edu/lgbtqi/research/gender-affirming-care/biased-science/ This report reflects the academic work of individual Yale faculty and does not represent the views of Yale University, Yale Law School, or Yale School of Medicine]." I believe attribution should resolve the issue, but placing it in the lead is undue.

6. Another reference used is by Trans Safety Network which isn't a publication but an [https://find-and-update.company-information.service.gov.uk/company/13739860  activist organization registered as a CIC in the UK]. It is an opinion and therefore should be attributed and placing it in the lead is unwarranted.

SEGM has been discussed positively in major publications, like ''[[The Economist]]'' described it as "an international group of concerned clinicians" on [https://www.economist.com/briefing/2023/04/05/the-evidence-to-support-medicalised-gender-transitions-in-adolescents-is-worryingly-weak 5 April 2023], a non-profit group on [https://www.economist.com/united-states/2022/07/28/questioning-americas-approach-to-transgender-health-care 28 July 2022], an international group of doctors and researchers on [https://www.economist.com/international/2020/12/12/an-english-ruling-on-transgender-teens-could-have-global-repercussions 12 December 2020], so the current description is not justified. Some other publications like ''[[AP News]]'' describe it as a "nonprofit group of health professionals who are concerned about medical transition risks for minors" on [https://www.latimes.com/science/story/2022-05-04/early-transgender-identity-endures-study-suggests 4 May 2022], ''[[The Australian]]'' described it as "A new international watchdog, the Society for Evidence-Based Gender Medicine, which includes clinicians with expertise in gender dysphoria" [https://www.proquest.com/docview/2568465547 on 1 May 2020] and as "new global body" [https://www.proquest.com/docview/2371886702].

So, coming to my question. Should we describe SEGM as "It is not recognized as a scientific organization by the international medical community" in the lead based on brief mentions in ''The Advocate'', opinion of spokesperson in ''Medscape'', or description in local publications like ''WyoFile'' that cites some other source for that description. In my opinion, it is ill-defined when reliable sources like ''The Economist'', ''The Australian'', ''AP News'' describe it differently. I tried to find such mention in scientific organizations/watchdogs that may have officially described SEGM in this manner. However, upon further research, no such statements from specific organizations could be identified.

Thus, we should work on revising the lead paragraph to present a more objective and neutral perspective, avoiding the selective use of quotes. This will ensure that the information provided is both accurate and reliable, in accordance with Wikipedia's guidelines. [[User:Colaheed777|Colaheed777]] ([[User talk:Colaheed777|talk]]) 20:28, 19 May 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Categorization of people#rfc_ABE1E8D|Wikipedia talk:Categorization of people]] expired 2023-05-20 18:03 ===
* Id: ABE1E8D
* User: Biruitorul
* Date: 2023-04-20 17:44:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1150903701|POLICY 1150903701}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1155990385|POLICY 1155990385}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I propose amending the following phrase from the guideline: “historical persons may be identified by notable association with a single heritage” to “historical persons may be identified by notable association with zero or more heritages”. — [[User:Biruitorul|Biruitorul]] <small><sup>[[User talk:Biruitorul|Talk]]</sup></small> 17:44, 20 April 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Alchemical symbol#rfc_417B2F4|Talk:Alchemical symbol]] expired 2023-05-21 03:03 ===
* Id: 417B2F4
* User: Kwamikagami
* Date: 2023-04-21 02:40:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|1150968157|SCI 1150968157}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|1156081182|SCI 1156081182}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Do we have adequate reason to include ⚩ as an alchemical symbol for 'magnesium'?
There are two references. The first one is a reference to Unicode 5; by Unicode 6, the identity of ⚩ as 'magnesium' had been retracted. (I contacted Unicode about this: see previous thread.) And, of course, Unicode definitions are not a RS for alchemy, only for Unicode. 
The second ref appears to be a smoke-screen, with no mention of the symbol. At best, it appears to be a tenuous OR chain trying to equate magnesium with magnesia. [[User:Kwamikagami|— kwami]] ([[User talk:Kwamikagami|talk]]) 02:40, 21 April 2023 (UTC)}}
