=== [[Talk:Transnational authoritarianism#rfc_759F563|Talk:Transnational authoritarianism]] expired 2023-05-21 10:01 ===
* Id: 759F563
* User: MINQI
* Date: 2023-05-14 08:59:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1154729790|HIST 1154729790}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1156132062|HIST 1156132062}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Before what I have done (as [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Transnational_authoritarianism&oldid=1150925517 the version at 20:41, 20 April 2023‎] ),there are two main Problems about the Page "Transnational authoritarianism":

1.Most sources are using and talking about "Transnational repression" but they are written here as "Transnational authoritarianism" , for example:It is "Typology of Transnational Repression" by [https://academic.oup.com/socpro/article/63/4/480/2402855?login=false the source], but here "Typology of transnational authoritarianism". Is that go against [[Wikipedia:No original research]] and [[Wikipedia:Verifiability]]? Or "Transnational repression" ="Transnational authoritarianism" ?

2.I can not find the quote to "A number of actors; principally countries governed by authoritarian states are known to engage in transnational repression of dissident and diaspora communities abroad including but not limited to: China, Saudi Arabia, Rwanda, Turkey and Iran. " and "A range of states engage in these actions, from Russian assassinations to forced disappearances of Chinese and Hong Kong citizens abroad. Freedom House details the extensive use of transnational authoritarianism by a rising number of countries across the world.". Are these [[Wikipedia:SYNTH|"Synthesis of published material"]]: A. These countries are authoritarian states + B.These countries have transnational repression → C. These countries are transnational authoritarianism?

Since most sources used "transnational repression", should it be moved from "Transnational authoritarianism" to "Transnational Repression"? And take "Transnational authoritarianism" as a subset of "Transnational Repression", because  transnational authoritarianism is "an authoritarian state repress one or more existing or potential members of its emigrant or diaspora communities". The essence of transnational authoritarian is transnational repression.

PS:I am still want to know about the definition of the situation of  Edward Snowden. He is forced to in exile in russia([https://www.cfr.org/interview/extraditing-edward-snowden "From Snowden’s perspective, the U.S. government is seeking his return for the purpose of persecuting him..".];[https://edition.cnn.com/2013/06/24/politics/nsa-snowden-options/index.html “We have forced him effectively into exile ...”]), so is he under the transnational repression from U.S. government? If not, why? [[User:MINQI|MINQI]] ([[User talk:MINQI|talk]]) 08:59, 14 May 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Edit filter helper#rfc_53AC113|Wikipedia talk:Edit filter helper]] expired 2023-05-21 11:01 ===
* Id: 53AC113
* User: Illusion Flame
* Date: 2023-04-21 10:46:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1151012352|POLICY 1151012352}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1156138839|POLICY 1156138839}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
 There have been multiple good-faith requests for Edit Filter Helper (EFH) recently. These include editors that have been active for 1-2 months requesting EFH and being declined due to lack of experience. Many voters have stated that they would want a EFH to have been a Wikipedian for at least 6 months. The current policy only requires 1 month. I propose changing the criteria from:

In addition to the above requirements, the candidate must also meet at least one of the following criteria:

Currently-active extended confirmed editor on the English Wikipedia (i.e. has made edits or logged actions within the last 12 months)

Current administrator on another WMF project

Current edit filter manager on another WMF project

Current WMF developer or staff member who needs access for WMF-related purposes


to


In addition to the above requirements, the candidate must also meet at least one of the following criteria:

Has been an active<ref>(i.e. has made edits or logged actions within the last 12 months)</ref> member of the English Wikipedia for at least six months and has made over 1,000 edits 

Current administrator on another WMF project

Current edit filter manager on another WMF project

Current WMF developer or staff member who needs access for WMF-related purposes - 🔥[[User:Illusion Flame|𝑰𝒍𝒍𝒖𝒔𝒊𝒐𝒏 𝑭𝒍𝒂𝒎𝒆]] [[User talk:Illusion Flame|(𝒕𝒂𝒍𝒌)]]🔥 10:46, 21 April 2023 (UTC)}}

* [[WP:NPOVHOW]]: {{talkquote|.. Generally, do not remove sourced information from the encyclopedia solely because it seems biased. Instead, try to rewrite the passage or section to achieve a more neutral tone. Biased information can usually be balanced with material cited to other sources to produce a more neutral perspective, so such problems should be fixed when possible through the normal editing process. ..}}

Wikipedia has a neutral point of view (NPOV) policy that requires all content to be written in a way that is unbiased, accurate, and free from personal opinion or advocacy. This means that controversial or negative information about a subject should not be removed solely because it is unflattering or inconvenient.criticism with various different sources and if it is notable, it shouldn't be removed. [[User:Nyovuu|Nyovuu]] ([[User talk:Nyovuu|talk]]) 11:41, 18 May 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Ronald Reagan#rfc_321FC37|Talk:Ronald Reagan]] expired 2023-05-22 17:02 ===
* Id: 321FC37
* User: Jaydenwithay
* Date: 2023-04-27 13:58:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1151991894|POL 1151991894}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1153331373|BIO 1153331373}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1153331380|HIST 1153331380}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1156395592|BIO 1156395592}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1156395595|HIST 1156395595}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1156395599|POL 1156395599}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Shall the third paragraph of the lede mention "a delayed response to the AIDS epidemic"? 

HIV/AIDS is arguably the most influential and pervading disease of the second half of the 20th and the 21st centuries, and Reagan's reaction is still consequential today, with more than 700,000 Americans as of today dead of the virus. I think that the RfC on this topic from several years ago was properly sourced and valid, but their sentence was not optimal as far as WP:NPOV goes. 

My proposed sentence at the moment would be '''"Reagan also headed a delayed governmental response to the AIDS epidemic during his tenure."''' This would be located the end of the third paragraph of the lede, since that paragraph as written right now is split between first and second terms. This sentences ''does not'' says that he personally "ignored" the crisis, which is an admittedly subjective view, but does specify that the response was not very proactive, which is [https://www.c-span.org/classroom/document/?17826 a statement] largely agreed upon by many [https://www.history.com/news/aids-epidemic-ronald-reagan historians] and [https://www.jstor.org/stable/23253449 scholars] and in the news media [https://exhibits.library.gsu.edu/out-in-the-archives/hiv-aids/reagans-response/ both] [https://www.nytimes.com/1985/09/18/us/reagan-defends-financing-for-aids.html contemporaneously] [https://www.msnbc.com/msnbc/when-aids-was-funny-short-film-reveals-shortfalls-reagan-response-aids-msna735296 and] [https://apnews.com/article/b220ec4793a64a11b657f44f59232afb retrospectively]. 

[[User:Jaydenwithay|Jaydenwithay]] ([[User talk:Jaydenwithay|talk]]) 13:58, 27 April 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:October Surprise conspiracy theory#rfc_B82787D|Talk:October Surprise conspiracy theory]] expired 2023-05-27 20:03 ===

=== [[Talk:Charles III#rfc_2D130CE|Talk:Charles III]] expired 2023-05-28 05:02 ===
* Id: 2D130CE
* Date: 2023-04-28 04:30:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1152095354|HIST 1152095354}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1152095356|POL 1152095356}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1152095360|SOC 1152095360}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1157368767|HIST 1157368767}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1157368770|POL 1157368770}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1157368773|SOC 1157368773}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Input is requested regarding how to end the opening sentence of this article, following the words "Charles III (Charles Philip Athur George; born 14 November 1948)..." Prior discussion on the matter has taken place [[#Lede|here]] and [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject British Royalty/Charles III task force#Lead section|here]].

Presently, there are six options:

# is king of [[Commonwealth realm|14 independent countries]], in addition to the [[United Kingdom]].
# is king of 14 independent countries, in addition to the [[United Kingdom]], collectively known as the [[Commonwealth realm]]s.
# is king of [[Commonwealth realm|15 independent countries]], including the [[United Kingdom]].
# is [[king of the United Kingdom]] and the 14 other [[Commonwealth realms]].
# is [[king of the United Kingdom]] and 14 other independent countries, all known as the [[Commonwealth realm]]s.
# is [[king of the United Kingdom]], [country], [country], [country], and the [X] other [[Commonwealth realms]]. [Which countries are named depending on a to-be-determined criteria]

Issues of concern appear to be, so far:

* Brevity (without sacrificing accuracy of information, both explicit and implied)
* Giving prominence to the United Kingdom/Charles' role as king of the United Kingdom
* Not relegating countries that belong to the G7, G20, TPP, NATO, and/or are otherwise relatively significant on the global stage into a diminished group of "other"
* Expressing the reality of the equality of status between the Commonwealth realms and Charles' offices as king of each
* The difference between role and title
* Reader unfamiliarity with the term "Commonwealth realm"

Please state your preference or preferences in order of preference. The aim is to form a consensus within the next week, ahead of Charles' coronation on 6 May; though, it is acknowledged that this may not happen. 04:30, 28 April 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:What Wikipedia is not#rfc_C095E38|Wikipedia talk:What Wikipedia is not]] expired 2023-05-28 23:02 ===
* Id: C095E38
* User: WhatamIdoing
* Date: 2023-04-28 22:22:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1152224374|POLICY 1152224374}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1157484472|POLICY 1157484472}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
This policy says {{xt|To provide encyclopedic value, data should be put in context with explanations referenced to independent sources.}}

I believe that some editors, especially less experienced editors, would benefit from some idea of what it means to put information in context.  I therefore propose adding a link to [[Wikipedia:Writing better articles#Provide context for the reader]] (e.g., so that it reads {{xt|To provide encyclopedic value, data should be [[Wikipedia:Writing better articles#Provide context for the reader|put in context]] with explanations referenced to independent sources}}).  What do you think?  [[User:WhatamIdoing|WhatamIdoing]] ([[User talk:WhatamIdoing|talk]]) 22:22, 28 April 2023 (UTC)}}

{{rfcquote|text=
How should the fork and libreboot.at be included?
# Ignore it like article <s>does now</s> did when RfC started
# Include basic history and info based on primary sources if independent secondary sources are not available
# Other

Background: There is a dispute over the direction of Libreboot, and the name is now being used by two projects. The new GNU/FSF website[https://libreboot.at/][https://web.archive.org/web/20230320220851/https://libreboot.at/] and project was announced in March at a Libreplanet presentation.[https://media.libreplanet.org/u/libreplanet/m/taking-control-over-the-means-of-production-free-software-boot/] Some discussion of issues is at libreboot.org.[https://libreboot.org/news/policy.html]

At this article, these changes, [[Special:Diff/1146204066/1149329352]], on April 11, added a basic statement, but were reverted and called "VANDALISM" by these changes, [[Special:Diff/1149329352/1152487905]], on April 30.

=== [[Template talk:Infobox person#rfc_904B484|Template talk:Infobox person]] expired 2023-06-02 09:06 ===
* Id: 904B484
* User: Nikkimaria#David Bowie]]'''. Should template documentation be changed? Or some other clarification be sought? How say you all? &ndash;&nbsp;[[User:.Raven
* Date: 2023-06-02 01:23:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1158113991|BIO 1158113991}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1158160013|BIO 1158160013}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
== How narrowly to read "city" of birth/death? '''

The infoboxes of [[Pearl Mackie]], [[Peter Hawkins]], [[Danny Kirwan]], and [[Tony Sewell, Baron Sewell of Sanderstead]] read "Born... [[Brixton]], London, England". For a short while, so did the infobox for [[David Bowie]]; then "Brixton" was removed from that last infobox, on the grounds that only a "city" should be named, and Brixton is not a city (though it has a larger population than 17 of the USA's state capitals, and in-real-life form fields marked "city" are routinely filled in with names of other place-types – town, village, etc. – where appropriate).  How narrowly should that word "city" be read? This has been discussed by {{ping|Bretonbanquet|Nikkimaria}} and me, at '''[[User talk:Nikkimaria#David Bowie]]'''. Should template documentation be changed? Or some other clarification be sought? How say you all? &ndash;&nbsp;[[User:.Raven|<big>'''.'''</big>Raven]]&nbsp;<sup>[[User talk:.Raven|&nbsp;'''''.'''talk'']]</sup> 01:23, 2 June 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Samuel Dash#rfc_D87BD75|Talk:Samuel Dash]] expired 2023-06-04 09:03 ===
* Id: D87BD75
* User: Hmoon9
* Date: 2023-06-04 03:03:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1158445765|BIO 1158445765}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1158445767|POLICY 1158445767}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1158475538|BIO 1158475538}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1158475541|POLICY 1158475541}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Samuel Dash attended Central High School in Philadelphia, and I recently stumbled upon a photograph of him in that high school's June 2, 1942 edition of the school's newspaper. I found a handful of these newspapers when looking through my grandfather's old things. The photograph is a black and white portrait of Samuel Dash in a suit along with a short article about him titled "Dash and ILSA Move To Aid in War Effort". The high school newspaper was called the "The Centralizer", and the photograph in question was in the Vol. XXXIX No. 10 June 2, 1942 edition of the newspaper. No copyright identifiers or indications are contained anywhere in the newspaper.

My question is, would it be permissible to include this photograph in the Samuel Dash article? Would this pose any copyright issues? And, would this pose any privacy related issues? [[User:Hmoon9|Hmoon9]] ([[User talk:Hmoon9|talk]]) 03:03, 4 June 2023 (UTC)}}

* RFC Text:

The table listing the Awards has no citations.  

It was removed from the article by this edit, because it is unsourced:
https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=The_Adventures_of_Priscilla%2C_Queen_of_the_Desert&diff=1156503955&oldid=1152957036

https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=The_Adventures_of_Priscilla%2C_Queen_of_the_Desert&diff=1157091434&oldid=1157090908

Should the table be removed from the article as long as it is unsourced?

=== [[Talk:Charles III#rfc_4A8D672|Talk:Charles III]] expired 2023-06-05 09:05 ===
* Id: 4A8D672
* User: Estar8806
* Date: 2023-05-07 02:55:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1153561359|BIO 1153561359}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1153561362|HIST 1153561362}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1153561366|POL 1153561366}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1158765824|BIO 1158765824}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1158765826|HIST 1158765826}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1158765829|POL 1158765829}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the infoboxes for [[Charles III]] (and other descendants of [[Elizabeth II]] and [[Philip Mountbatten]], and by extension their respective spouses where appropriate) include a mention of their agnatic descent from the house to which Prince Philip belonged. This is done for [[Juliana of the Netherlands|Juliana]], [[Beatrix of the Netherlands|Beatrix]] and [[Willem-Alexander]] of the Netherlands and for [[Jean, Grand Duke of Luxembourg]] and [[Henri, Grand Duke of Luxembourg]].

If the agnatic house is included should it be:
* the [[House of Glücksburg]], the house of the [[kings of Greece]] from which Philip (and therefore his children) biologically descend; or
* the [[House of Mountbatten]], the house in which Philip was 'adopted' before his marriage to Elizabeth in 1947, and therefore the house to which he would have technically belonged when his children were born?

Both houses are mentioned on Philip's article.

''For simplicity, responses in the format of '''Support (Glücksburg)''', '''Support (Mountbatten)''', or '''Oppose''' are preferable''

Cheers! [[User:Estar8806|Estar8806]] ([[User talk:Estar8806|talk]]) 02:55, 7 May 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Long-term abuse#rfc_0F31C7F|Wikipedia talk:Long-term abuse]] expired 2023-06-06 11:02 ===
* Id: 0F31C7F
* User: 2620:8D:8000:10A6:71B7:9282:F1A9:BA79
* Date: 2023-05-20 20:54:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/WikiProjects_and_collaborations|prev|1156023152|PROJ 1156023152}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/WikiProjects_and_collaborations|prev|1158810133|PROJ 1158810133}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
One thing leads to another.  I saw a bunch of LTA pages that should have been archived and requested that to be done [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Wikipedia_talk%3ALong-term_abuse&diff=1155307186&oldid=1149736158#Semi-protected_edit_request_on_17_May_2023].  

Looking at the discussion, I saw that one admin recommended that the page be marked historical due to a relative lack of recent edits over the past 7-8 years [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Wikipedia:Help_desk&oldid=1155828003#WP:ER_on_WP:LTA].  

I think Wikipedia has gotten better at preventing long-term abuse, so the number of LTAs has declined in the past few years.  Many vandals also celebrate the recognition they get from these kinds of pages. The Long-term abuse page should be marked as historical. What do you think? [[Special:Contributions/2620:8D:8000:10A6:71B7:9282:F1A9:BA79|2620:8D:8000:10A6:71B7:9282:F1A9:BA79]] ([[User talk:2620:8D:8000:10A6:71B7:9282:F1A9:BA79|talk]]) 20:54, 20 May 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)#rfc_8542B59|Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)]] expired 2023-06-07 11:01 ===
* Id: 8542B59
* User: Prarambh20
* Date: 2023-06-06 21:17:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|1158891793|RELI 1158891793}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1158891795|SOC 1158891795}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|1158891798|TECH 1158891798}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|1158891799|PROP 1158891799}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|1158968790|RELI 1158968790}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1158968792|SOC 1158968792}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|1158968794|TECH 1158968794}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|1158968798|PROP 1158968798}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should pages in the Category:Emotion and other related pages on human expression have a dedicated Infobox, either an existing one or a new Infobox (such as Template:Infobox emotion) specifically designed for emotions?

Currently, all the pages related to emotions, moods, and virtues do not include an Infobox. While it is true that the topic of "Emotion" is best expressed and explained through descriptive phrases, an Infobox can provide a concise overview of general information and characteristics of a particular emotion at a glance. Additionally, it may assist readers in understanding the basic features, specifications, and related groups of an emotion or expression. According to the [[MOS:INFOBOXUSE]], no page is prohibited from having an Infobox, nor is it mandatory. Therefore, utilizing an Infobox could potentially enhance the presentation of information in a structured and easily understandable format. 

To provide a basic idea, an Infobox about emotions could include parameters such as the extreme and mild versions of the emotion, synonyms, opposites, opposite extreme and mild emotions, dyads (based on the [[Emotion classification#Plutchik's wheel of emotions|wheel of emotions]]), primary, secondary, and tertiary groups of the emotion, disposition or outlook, term meaning and origin, as well as general characteristics like symptoms, expression, causes, specialty, duration, evolution, treatment, diagnosis, coping mechanisms, and neurological or psychological factors. However, it's important to note that these are general ideas for the potential information that could be included. 

In conclusion, considering the benefits an Infobox can provide in terms of presenting information in a structured and accessible manner, it is worth considering whether the pages in the Category:Emotions and related topics should have an Infobox.[[User:Prarambh20|Prarambh20]] ([[User talk:Prarambh20|talk]]) 21:17, 6 June 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Glass#rfc_E3F5801|Talk:Glass]] expired 2023-06-09 12:01 ===
* Id: E3F5801
* User: Polyamorph#top
* Date: 2023-05-30 07:54:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|1157679598|SCI 1157679598}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|1157679600|MEDIA 1157679600}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|1159289337|SCI 1159289337}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|1159289342|MEDIA 1159289342}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the current image be replaced? Consensus is needed on the most appropriate image to use as the main image in this article. The current image shows a glass building facade; it is a [[Commons:Quality images|Quality image]], used when the article was promoted to GA, and is instantly recognisable as glass of the most common and widespread type. However, it has been criticized as an oversimplification of what glass is and a somewhat corporate and "generic picture". An alternative has been proposed which shows a glass figurine being manufactured; while it might be less recognisable it shows glass in it's 'raw' form in both the molten and solid-state, indicating how glass can be used to make a variety of products and forms. The two images under discussion are provided below. 
{{Gallery
|title = Main image options
|File:Fassade Wilhelmstrasse 65, Berlin-Mitte, 160417, ako.jpg
 | '''Current image'''
| File:The making of a tiny glass elephant 04.jpg
 | '''Proposed replacement'''
}}
Best wishes, <small>'''''[[User:Polyamorph|Polyamorph]]''''' ([[User talk:Polyamorph#top|talk]])</small> 07:54, 30 May 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Bahá?í Faith#rfc_F6BAA3E|Talk:Bahá?í Faith]] expired 2023-06-10 02:03 ===
* Id: F6BAA3E
* User: Asad29591
* Date: 2023-05-11 01:30:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|1154664055|RELI 1154664055}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|1159395170|RELI 1159395170}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
This is a request for comment on whether the Orthodox Baháʼí Faith should be included in the see also section of the Baháʼí Faith article. The Orthodox Baháʼí Faith is a Baha'i sect that believes in the continuation of the Guardianship of the Baháʼí Faith after Shoghi Effendi. The mainstream Baháʼís consider them as Covenant-breakers and do not recognize their legitimacy. The dispute is about whether the link to the Orthodox Baháʼí Faith Wikipedia page is relevant and notable enough to be included in the see also section. The discussion on the talk page has reached an impasse, with one editor arguing for inclusion and another editor arguing for removal. Please provide your opinions on this issue and help resolve this dispute. Thank you.--[[User:Asad29591|Asad29591]] ([[User talk:Asad29591|talk]]) 01:30, 11 May 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:The Star-Spangled Banner#rfc_4B7C8D0|Talk:The Star-Spangled Banner]] expired 2023-06-10 15:01 ===
* Id: 4B7C8D0
* User: 179.54.211.52
* Date: 2023-05-13 17:28:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|1159407226|UNSORTED 1159407226}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|1159473195|UNSORTED 1159473195}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
 days remaining on RfC.
{{User:ClueBot III/DoNotArchiveUntil|1687024909}}
As discussed previously, in the edit request above, i propose the re-addition of the full lyrics to "The Star-Spangled Banner" to this article.

Users @[[User:Binksternet|Binksternet]] and @[[User:Magnolia677|Magnolia677]] have removed all but the first stanza of the US national anthem. The guideline they cited, [[WP:NOTLYRICS]] has a clear exception for songs such as national anthems, which this article is about. When justifying their edits, Magnolia677 stated that their concern was that the full lyrics were 32 lines long, ignoring the pages of longer anthems, such as those of Turkey's [[İstiklal Marşı]] (40 lines) and Italy's [[Il Canto degli Italiani]] (48 lines not counting chorus) among others. The question is, should the full lyrics be included in the article, or not? Use the Support template if yes, and the Oppose template if no. Should the consensus be in favor of re-addition, the lyrics will be re-added to the article, either by me or another editor. If you're not sure about your opinion, but want to support or oppose, consult the appropriate policies for advice. Thanks for reading and discussing. [[Special:Contributions/179.54.211.52|179.54.211.52]] ([[User talk:179.54.211.52|talk]]) 17:28, 13 May 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Incels.is#rfc_0CC9853|Talk:Incels.is]] expired 2023-06-10 17:01 ===
* Id: 0CC9853
* User: 2001:48F8:3004:FC4:48EA:35CE:A536:B342
* Date: 2023-06-10 14:01:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1159473193|SOC 1159473193}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1159487773|SOC 1159487773}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The deletion deletion was closed early as consensus merge https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Articles_for_deletion/Incels.is. Yet, all of it took place to before the article was substantially improved (x4 in size, new sources). Is the need still there to merge for the new article? Most of the nomination seems to be inaccurate now, on the new article. I do not see any overlap or similarities with the merge target. (also, as stated in the AfD, I believe that the resulting [[incel]] article would become too big and a [[WP:COATRACK]] if this was also merged to it) [[Special:Contributions/2001:48F8:3004:FC4:48EA:35CE:A536:B342|2001:48F8:3004:FC4:48EA:35CE:A536:B342]] ([[User talk:2001:48F8:3004:FC4:48EA:35CE:A536:B342|talk]]) 14:01, 10 June 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:The Star-Spangled Banner#rfc_7FF96D8|Talk:The Star-Spangled Banner]] expired 2023-06-12 18:02 ===
* Id: 7FF96D8
* User: 179.54.211.52
* Date: 2023-05-13 17:28:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|1154634897|MEDIA 1154634897}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1155352867|HIST 1155352867}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1155352872|SOC 1155352872}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1159812826|HIST 1159812826}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|1159812829|MEDIA 1159812829}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1159812831|SOC 1159812831}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
As discussed previously, in the edit request above, i propose the re-addition of the full lyrics to "The Star-Spangled Banner" to this article.

Users @[[User:Binksternet|Binksternet]] and @[[User:Magnolia677|Magnolia677]] have removed all but the first stanza of the US national anthem. The guideline they cited, [[WP:NOTLYRICS]] has a clear exception for songs such as national anthems, which this article is about. When justifying their edits, Magnolia677 stated that their concern was that the full lyrics were 32 lines long, ignoring the pages of longer anthems, such as those of Turkey's [[İstiklal Marşı]] (40 lines) and Italy's [[Il Canto degli Italiani]] (48 lines not counting chorus) among others. The question is, should the full lyrics be included in the article, or not? Use the Support template if yes, and the Oppose template if no. Should the consensus be in favor of re-addition, the lyrics will be re-added to the article, either by me or another editor. If you're not sure about your opinion, but want to support or oppose, consult the appropriate policies for advice. Thanks for reading and discussing. [[Special:Contributions/179.54.211.52|179.54.211.52]] ([[User talk:179.54.211.52|talk]]) 17:28, 13 May 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Video games#rfc_B723984|Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Video games]] expired 2023-06-13 18:02 ===
* Id: B723984
* User: TheJoebro64
* Date: 2023-05-26 14:13:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|1157133657|MEDIA 1157133657}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|1159970349|MEDIA 1159970349}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
This RfC seeks to address whether the review aggregator [[OpenCritic]] should be adopted alongside [[Metacritic]], our current standard. [[Template_talk:Video_game_reviews/Archive_5#Adding_OpenCritic_as_a_review_aggregator|The last RfC from 2017]] concluded that, at the time, OpenCritic was not cited by enough [[WP:RS|reliable sources]] to justify its inclusion, in addition to concerns that its average scores were too similar to Metacritic's (creating a redundancy problem). The issue has cropped up again from time to time and there seems to be agreement amongst editors that the situation has changed enough to warrant another RfC.

One point of contention is that OpenCritic has become far more mainstream. ''[[Video Games Chronicle]]'' regularly cites OpenCritic (examples: [https://www.videogameschronicle.com/news/the-lord-of-the-rings-gollum-is-the-worst-reviewed-game-of-2023/][https://www.videogameschronicle.com/news/lost-ark-has-topped-20-million-players-worldwide/][https://www.videogameschronicle.com/news/elden-ring-looks-likely-to-have-smashed-souls-sales-records-in-the-uk/]), its ranking of a certain game attracted considerable attention in sources considered reliable at [[WP:VG/S]] recently (examples: [https://www.videogameschronicle.com/news/zelda-tears-of-the-kingdom-is-the-highest-rated-game-ever-on-opencritic/], [https://www.vg247.com/zelda-tears-of-the-kingdom-highest-rated-game-all-time], [https://www.nintendolife.com/news/2023/05/zelda-tears-of-the-kingdom-is-now-the-highest-rated-game-of-all-time-on-opencritic], [https://www.shacknews.com/article/135456/zelda-tears-of-the-kingdom-totk-opencritic-highest-rated]), and both [[Epic Games Store]] ([https://www.gamesindustry.biz/epic-games-stores-avoids-review-bombing-with-opencritic-integration]) and [[GOG.com]] ([https://www.gog.com/news/gog_2022_update_6_opencritic_reviews_on_our_gamecards]) have integrated it into game listings. It is safe to say that the situation regarding OpenCritic's presence in reliable sources is not the same as it was in 2017.

Another common point of contention concerns the site's Critics Recommend metric, which is a different form of measurement from the averages that Metacritic and OpenCritic itself provide. Rather than averaging review scores, Critics Recommend designates reviews as positive or negative and uses them to provide a percentage, similar to [[Rotten Tomatoes]]' Tomatometer. [[Wikipedia_talk:WikiProject_Video_games/Archive_156#OpenCritic_Percentage_Recommended_Score|A 2021 discussion regarding incorporating this metric specifically]] ended in no consensus, although by headcount a narrow majority of editors supported the proposal. [[User:TheJoebro64|<small style="color:red">JOE</small>]][[User talk:TheJoebro64|<small>BRO</small>]][[Special:Contributions/TheJoebro64|<sup style="color:#D18719">64</sup>]] 14:13, 26 May 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Serbia#rfc_D87C52F|Talk:Serbia]] expired 2023-06-13 20:03 ===
* Id: D87C52F
* User: TylerBurden
* Date: 2023-05-14 19:03:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1154809213|POL 1154809213}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Music#rfc_CFA755C|Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Music]] expired 2023-06-13 21:02 ===
* Id: CFA755C
* User: 81.157.51.237
* Date: 2023-05-14 20:35:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|1154816678|MEDIA 1154816678}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|1160002020|MEDIA 1160002020}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I see two major problems with Larkin's ratings system (at least in the context of Wikipedia):

1) He does not "score" albums out of five in the style of a ''Rolling Stone'' or ''Record Mirror''. ''The Encyclopedia of Popular Music'' states that Larkin and his team's system is "different to most 5 star ratings in that ''we rate according to the artist in question's work''. Therefore, a 4 star album from the Beatles will have the overall edge over a 4 star album by Chicory Tip." This makes Larkin's ratings incongruent with other scores included in scores boxes on album articles, as he could conceivably hold X's 1-star album to be as accomplished as Y's 5-star album.

2) ''Larkin's system is inherently non-objective''. By his own admission, his ratings are influenced by "review ratings of the credible music journals and critics' opinions". As well as leaning on the opinions of others, what is "credible", is of course, highly subjective.

I don't see any issue with Wikipedia continuing to use Larkin's ''prose'', but I believe it should be written into the music Manual of Style that we avoid his album ratings. Hopefully this will foster some discussion. Thanks. [[Special:Contributions/81.157.51.237|81.157.51.237]] ([[User talk:81.157.51.237|talk]]) 20:35, 14 May 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Template talk:Infobox aircraft#rfc_4BF5EBE|Template talk:Infobox aircraft]] expired 2023-06-14 11:01 ===
* Id: 4BF5EBE
* User: Prarambh20
* Date: 2023-06-09 18:17:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|1159344764|SCI 1159344764}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|1159344772|TECH 1159344772}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|1159344775|PROP 1159344775}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|1160091438|SCI 1160091438}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|1160091443|TECH 1160091443}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|1160091446|PROP 1160091446}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
As per the '''[[Wikipedia:Templates for discussion/Log/2023 January 22#Template:Infobox aircraft begin|consensus reached in the merger discussion]]''', the templates {{tl|Infobox aircraft begin}}, {{tl|Infobox aircraft type}}, {{tl|Infobox aircraft career}}, {{tl|Infobox aircraft engine}}, and {{tl|Infobox aircraft program}} are intended to be merged into "{{tl|Infobox aircraft}}". Based on the outcome of the merger discussion, '''two proposals''' have been presented: one suggesting a direct, common and singular merger of all the Infoboxes, and the other proposing an alternative approach rather than a common merge.

'''Proposal 1:''' [[Special:Permalink/1156443664|Merged Version]]:

This version involves a direct, comprehensive merger with the intention of creating a singular and standardized Infobox aircraft template. [[Special:Permalink/1156443664|The merged version]] incorporates all parameters and labels from each of the original Infoboxes, In some cases, similar parameters from those Infoboxes are presented under a common label. It also allows for simple replacement options and adheres to [[MOS:IB]].

''(The merged version refers to the current iteration of the Infobox aircraft.)''

Further discussions regarding the merged version: Initially, this merged version contained some spaces that were subsequently removed following discussions on the talk page. Additionally, it includes Infobox aircraft engine '''as decided in the TfD''', although some editors have expressed opposition to including aircraft engine, and have suggested initiating discussion challenging the TfD closing statement to deliberate whether or not to include the Infobox aircraft engine. However, a definitive conclusion has not yet been reached.

'''Proposal 2:''' [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Aircraft/Infobox refactor 2023|Alternative Approach]]:

An alternative approach has been presented in a two-step process, which advocates for maintaining standalone Infoboxes instead of merging them into a single Infobox. This approach suggests merging only {{tl|Infobox aircraft begin}} into each of the four Infoboxes, while proposing the replacement of Infobox aircraft engine with other engine-specific Infoboxes, such as reciprocating, turbine, rocket engines, and electric motors, based on the context of each page.

''For a clearer understanding of this alternative approach, we encourage you to review the discussions on the [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Aircraft/Infobox refactor 2023]] page.''

Now the question arises: should we adopt the merged version (Proposal1) or follow the alternative approach (Proposal2)?

*'''Option 1:''' Support the merged version as per Proposal 1. 
*'''Option 2:''' Support the merged version, excluding the Infobox aircraft engine. 
*'''Option 3:''' Support the alternative approach, Proposal 2. 
*'''Option 4:''' Support the alternative approach, but with modifications or additional considerations (please specify). 
*'''Other:''' (please provide your specific suggestion or proposal).

Thanks, -- [[User:Prarambh20|Prarambh20]] ([[User talk:Prarambh20|talk]]) 18:17, 9 June 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Neo-Confederates#rfc_85D98A2|Talk:Neo-Confederates]] expired 2023-06-17 14:01 ===
* Id: 85D98A2
* User: Wes sideman

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the following paragraph be included in the article?
{{Blockquote|
In the 1930s, self-described fascist publisher [[Seward Collins]] provided an avenue for white supremacists and neo-Confederates to advance their ideology in [[The American Review (literary journal)|The American Review]], a literary journal openly sympathetic to [[Fascism in Europe|European fascism]].<ref>{{cite book |last1=Hague |first1=Euan |last2=Beirich |first2=Heidi |last3=Sebesta |first3=Edward H. |title=Neo-Confederacy: A Critical Introduction |date=15 September 2009 |publisher=University of Texas Press |isbn=978-0-292-77921-1 |page=29 |url=https://www.google.com/books/edition/Neo_Confederacy/LfWdaR9wHEEC?hl=en&gbpv=1 |access-date=4 May 2023 |language=en}}</ref> The connections and overlap between white supremacist, fascist, far-right, and neo-Confederate ideologies have persisted and remain in place in the present day.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Omi |first1=Michael |last2=Winant |first2=Howard |title=Racial Formation in the United States |date=20 June 2014 |publisher=Routledge |isbn=978-1-135-12751-0 |page=260 |url=https://www.google.com/books/edition/Racial_Formation_in_the_United_States/T7LcAwAAQBAJ?hl=en&gbpv=1&pg=PA260&printsec=frontcover&printsec=frontcover |access-date=4 May 2023 |language=en}}</ref>}}[[User:Wes sideman|Wes sideman]]([[User talk:Wes sideman|talk]]) 13:55, 18 May 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:American Civil War#rfc_C3CC347|Talk:American Civil War]] expired 2023-06-18 02:01 ===
* Id: C3CC347
* User: Parham wiki
* Date: 2023-06-17 21:50:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1160645773|HIST 1160645773}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1160645774|POL 1160645774}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1160671418|HIST 1160671418}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1160671421|POL 1160671421}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Andrew Johnson, the law passed by Congress and the Supreme Court declared August 20, 1866 as the date of the end of the Civil War, while Infobox makes no mention of this date. Since I can't make a major edit without broad consensus, I've created an rfc to fix the problem.

* '''Option 1''': August 20, 1866 should be considered the end of the war instead of May 26, 1865.
* '''Option 2''': This date is good.
** '''Option 2A''': Write about this in note B.
** '''Option 2B''': No need to write it in the notes.
[[User:Parham wiki|Parham wiki]] ([[User talk:Parham wiki|talk]]) 21:50, 17 June 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:October Surprise conspiracy theory#rfc_3089EE3|Talk:October Surprise conspiracy theory]] expired 2023-06-20 23:01 ===
* Id: 3089EE3
* Date: 2023-06-20 17:39:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1161109739|POL 1161109739}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1161144251|POL 1161144251}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
{{requested move/dated|1980 October surprise theory}}

This RFC is meant to consider two move options: [[:October Surprise conspiracy theory]] → {{no redirect|1980 October surprise theory}} '''or''' → {{no redirect|1980 October surprise allegations}}  – A [[#RfC about the article title|recent RFC]] yielded a consensus that this article should be moved. As the closer said, "{{tq|there's consensus to change the title, but no consensus about what to change it to.}}" In a [[#Post RFC Discussion|post-rfc discussion]], users were generally split between two options: '''1980 October surprise allegations''' and '''1980 October surprise theory'''. Because editors seem evenly split on preferring allegations/theory (most editors say they support either), I've started an RFC to get broader community input--<span style="font-family:Georgia">'''[[User:Jerome Frank Disciple|Jerome Frank Disciple]]'''</span> 17:39, 20 June 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)#rfc_89D3B14|Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)]] expired 2023-06-21 18:01 ===
* Id: 89D3B14
* User: Wracking
* Date: 2023-06-09 05:43:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:

** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1159249361|POLICY 1159249361}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|1164428514|STYLE 1164428514}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1164428519|POLICY 1164428519}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should [[MOS:SECTIONCAPS]] recommend that, in a heading, the first letter after a colon is capitalized?

That is, should this example be reversed?

{{tqbm|''Use:'' {{xt|1891–1940: early history}}<br>''Avoid:'' {{!xt|1891–1940: Early history}}}}

Similar past discussions: [[Wikipedia_talk:Manual_of_Style/Capital_letters#Headings:_should_content_after_a_colon_be_capitalized?|May 2023]], [[Wikipedia_talk:Manual_of_Style/Capital_letters/Archive_35#Capitalization_in_section_headers_that_start_with_numbers|October 2022]], [[Wikipedia_talk:Manual_of_Style/Capital_letters/Archive_33#Caps_in_headers_that_start_with_numbers|March 2022]]. [[User:Wracking|<span style="font-variant:small-caps;border-radius:9em;background:#E0E8E0; color:#1a4c39; padding:4px;">Wracking</span>]]&nbsp;<sup>[[User talk:Wracking|talk!]]</sup> 05:43, 9 June 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Wikipedia#rfc_59ED436|Talk:Wikipedia]] expired 2023-06-23 06:01 ===
* Id: 59ED436
* User: CactiStaccingCrane
* Date: 2023-05-24 05:26:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|1156706640|MEDIA 1156706640}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|1156706644|PROP 1156706644}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|1161512101|MEDIA 1161512101}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|1161512102|PROP 1161512102}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Is the content below suitable for being the lead of the [[Wikipedia]] article?

'''Wikipedia'''{{notetag|Pronounced {{IPAc-en|audio=En-uk-Wikipedia.ogg|ˌ|w|ɪ|k|ᵻ|ˈ|p|iː|d|i|ə}} {{respell|wik|ih|PEE|dee|ə}} or {{IPAc-en|audio=en-us-Wikipedia.ogg|ˌ|w|ɪ|k|i|-}} {{respell|wik|ee|-}}}} is a [[Multilingualism|multilingual]] crowdsourced [[online encyclopedia]]. The content on Wikipedia is available without charge and is distributed under [[Free content|free content licenses]] ([[CC-BY 3.0|CC BY 3.0]] and [[GNU Free Documentation License|GDFL]] for texts), allowing for widespread use and furthering its goal of [[Democratization of knowledge|democratizing knowledge]]. At its core, Wikipedia aims to cover any topic that is above a [[Notability in the English Wikipedia|notability threshold]], based on external reliable sources, and its content must not contain [[Original Research|original research]] by its editors. Wikipedia is available in {{NUMBEROF|languages|Wikipedia}} languages and features a total of 61 million articles across all languages. Among them, the most popular language edition is the [[English Wikipedia]] with {{NUMBEROFARTICLES}} articles. Wikipedia as a whole is the most widely read [[reference work]] in history.<ref name="small screen">{{cite news |last=Cohen |first=Noam |author-link=Noam Cohen |date=February 9, 2014 |title=Wikipedia vs. the Small Screen |work=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/02/10/technology/wikipedia-vs-the-small-screen.html?_r=0 |url-status=live |url-access=limited |access-date=2023-01-22 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221109044012/https://www.nytimes.com/2014/02/10/technology/wikipedia-vs-the-small-screen.html?_r=0 |archive-date=2022-11-09}}</ref><ref name="Wikimedia_Stats">{{cite web |title=Wikistats – Statistics For Wikimedia Projects |url=https://stats.wikimedia.org/#/all-wikipedia-projects |access-date=November 18, 2020 |website=[[Wikimedia Foundation]] |publisher=}}</ref>

Almost all articles on Wikipedia are available for editing by registered editors and visitors. These articles are [[Open collaboration|collectively written]] via a [[wiki]] system; as such articles on Wikipedia generally provide more up-to-date information and have a wider range in reliability than paper encyclopedias. Though the [[Wikipedia community]] is popularly known by its [[Anarchy|anarchical]] structure, the community has adopted elements of [[Democracy|democratic]] and [[bureaucracy|bureaucratic]] systems, as demonstrated by the establishment of [[Wikipedia:User access levels|user rights]], policies, guidelines, and the final avenue of dispute resolution – the [[Arbitration Committee]].

Wikipedia was launched by [[Jimmy Wales]] and [[Larry Sanger]] on January 15, 2001, as a publicly editable encyclopedia initially associated with [[Nupedia]]. Both of these projects were owned by the [[Bomis]] company. As Wikipedia became increasingly more popular than Nupedia, its website experienced a rapid growth in content, editors, and language availability. In 2003, Wikipedia was transitioned from a commercial to a [[Nonprofit organization|non-profit]] encyclopedia and is now hosted by the [[Wikimedia Foundation]], based in the [[United States]]. Around late 2000s, as Wikipedia became [[List of most visited websites|one of the most visited websites]] in the world, the number of active editors reached its peak and has since remained stable.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Mandiberg |first=Michael |date=February 23, 2020 |title=Mapping Wikipedia |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2020/02/where-wikipedias-editors-are-where-they-arent-and-why/605023/ |url-access=subscription |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211115131524/https://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2020/02/where-wikipedias-editors-are-where-they-arent-and-why/605023/https://web.archive.org/web/20211115131524/https://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2020/02/where-wikipedias-editors-are-where-they-arent-and-why/605023/ |archive-date=November 15, 2021 |access-date=November 26, 2021 |website=The Atlantic |language=en}}</ref> Throughout its existence, Wikipedia consistently faced concerns about its [[Reliability of Wikipedia|reliability]], [[systemic bias]] and its [[Wikipedia community|editor base]], though over time the website began to be viewed more positively, largely due to the overall improvement in the quality of its articles.

– [[User:CactiStaccingCrane|CactiStaccingCrane]] ([[User talk:CactiStaccingCrane|talk]]) 05:26, 24 May 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Limburgish#rfc_9F2B5A6|Talk:Limburgish]] expired 2023-06-23 10:01 ===
* Id: 9F2B5A6
* User: Vlaemink
* Date: 2023-06-22 10:20:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Language_and_linguistics|prev|1161389310|LANG 1161389310}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Language_and_linguistics|prev|1161532806|LANG 1161532806}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
There's a series of ongoing disputes concerning the basic outline for this article; in essence, it's about what is consensus / traditional and what isn't. At his point in time, there are 5 active "sub discussions" taking place, and I would very much like to ask anyone familiar and/or interested in the area of Germanic linguistics to give their two cents on one or all of these matters. 

These are:  

*[[Talk:Limburgish#Point_1,_the_mainstream_categorization_of_Limburgish_as_part_of_Low_Franconian_&_use_of_"Meuse_Rhenish"|Whether or not the classification of Limburgish dialects as Low Franconian is mainstream/consensus]]
*[[Talk:Limburgish#Point_2,_Standard_Dutch_and_Standard_German_as_Dachsprachen/culture_languages_of_the_South_Low_Franconian_/_Limburgish_varieties|Whether or not the Dutch and German standard languages are considered the "culture languages" of the area in which Limburgish and similar dialects are spoken.]]
*[[Talk:Limburgish#Point_3,_the_validity_of_terminology|Whether "Middle Dutch" and "Old Dutch" (or "Old Limburgish" and "Middle Limburgish" are valid historical-linguistic terms within the linguistic field.]]
*[[Talk:Limburgish#Point_4,_fluent_dialectal_transitions|Whether the Limburgish dialects are considered to transition into neighboring dialects by linguistic consensus.]]
*[[Talk:Limburgish#Point_7,_unsourced_examples|Whether examples of vocabulary and grammar require sources.]]    

Thank you all very much in advance. Kind regards, [[User:Vlaemink|Vlaemink]] ([[User talk:Vlaemink|talk]]) 10:20, 22 June 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Article titles#rfc_DF9C165|Wikipedia talk:Article titles]] expired 2023-06-25 16:01 ===
* Id: DF9C165
* User: The C of E
* Date: 2023-06-24 08:09:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1161676762|SOC 1161676762}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|1161676765|STYLE 1161676765}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1161881212|SOC 1161881212}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|1161881213|STYLE 1161881213}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
For a long time with regard to the name of sports stadiums with sponsored names, it has generally been an unwritten rule on sports stadium articles (particularly in UK football and rugby related ones) that these names are not used for the title unless the stadium has never had a non-sponsored name to avoid Wikipedia being seen to endorse commercial entities. Henceforth, I wish to formalise this by proposing that a section be added to the Article Titles policy stating:
*"Where stadiums and arenas have been named after a sponsor, the original non-sponsored name shall always be used for the title (regardless of [[WP:COMMONNAME]]) unless the stadium has never had a non-sponsored name in its history." <span style="text-shadow:grey 0.5em 0.5em 0.6em;"> '''[[User:The C of E|<span style="color:red;">The C of E </span><span style="color:blue;"> God Save the King!</span>]]''' ([[User talk:The C of E|<span style="color:darkblue;">talk</span>]])</span> 08:09, 24 June 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard#rfc_8F0B573|Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard]] expired 2023-06-27 20:01 ===
* Id: 8F0B573
* User: Yae4
* Date: 2023-06-13 18:14:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|1159977197|SCI 1159977197}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|1165216544|SCI 1165216544}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Is [https://fossforce.com FossForce.com] a reliable source for [[Free and open-source software]] (FOSS) articles?
#Generally reliable
#Additional considerations apply
#Generally unreliable

With these edits at [[Libreboot]], {{u|PhotographyEdits}} removed cited info, claiming FossForce.com (and others) is not a [[WP:RS]]:
[[Special:Diff/1159945210 |one]], [[Special:Diff/1159103577 |two]], and [[Special:Diff/1040138399/1040596704 |2021 article purge and proposal to merge]]

Prevous RSN discussions: None found.

Talk discussions : [[Talk:/e/_(operating_system)#Recent_edits_by_User:Yae4 |one found]] in 2019; thin consensus, including me, was not reliable. {{u|Newslinger}} called it a "group blogs with no reputations".

An author "Christine Hall" is cited on a few editor talk pages, but I don't think it is the same Christine Hall.

About a dozen [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?search=insource%3Afossforce&title=Special:Search&profile=advanced&fulltext=1&ns0=1 articles cite FossForce.com].

Three cites that have been removed from [[Libreboot]] over time include:
*[https://fossforce.com/2016/09/libreboot-leaves-gnu-claiming-gender-identity-discrimination-fsf/ September 2016]
*[https://fossforce.com/2017/01/gnu-officially-boots-libreboot/ January 2017]
*[https://fossforce.com/2017/04/libreboot-reorganizes-seeks-amends/ April 2017]

*'''Option 2: Additional considerations apply''': While the articles are mostly by one author/editor, I contrast FossForce.com with somewhat similar (at a glance) liliputing.com, which was deemed generally unreliable blog, self-published source [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Reliable_sources/Noticeboard/Archive_278#Liliputing.com_blog_as_a_reliable_source? in this RSN discussion and RfC]. FossForce, to me, covers FOSS topics with more insight than just re-publicizing a single press release or vendor post, and discusses the info in some detail. FossForce also covers FOSS topics - not just new products up for sale - over time, as shown by the three cites above. While the FossForce website does show advertisements, it again contrasts with Liliputing by NOT being affiliate-spam directly connected to PR announcements about products being written about. Therefore, I feel this otherwise marginal source should be allowed, particularly for FOSS articles with few generally reliable sources.
:The present intention is to use the 2017 cites to support statements about the History of Libreboot without the personal [[WP:BLP]] info. They have been used differently at [[Libreboot]] previously. -- [[User:Yae4|Yae4]] ([[User talk:Yae4|talk]]) 18:14, 13 June 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard#rfc_5238E5C|Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard]] expired 2023-06-27 20:01 ===
* Id: 5238E5C
* User: Zefr
* Date: 2023-05-28 19:26:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|1157465247|PROP 1157465247}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|1162227154|PROP 1162227154}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
[[Wikipedia:Reliable_sources/Noticeboard/Archive_407|A May 2023 RSN discussion about Healthline]] raises the question about whether Healthline should be deprecated as generally unreliable or blacklisted as fabrication and spam on many of its health-related article pages. 

[[Healthline]]: [http://www.healthline.com/]

Healthline is frequently used by novice editors to source medical, nutrition, and lifestyle content. Its name implies health expertise, and its author(s) or editors are identified as having "medically reviewed" articles, despite most having no medical expertise (BS or MS degrees in non-medical fields). Healthline commonly cites individual primary studies to extrapolate to an anti-disease effect or "health benefit", a term used in many of its articles on foods, phytochemicals, and supplements.

Previous RSN discussion: Feb 2022 [[Wikipedia:Reliable_sources/Noticeboard/Archive_366#Nutritional_information_(Healthline/USDA)|goji berries]]

Examples of spam health misinformation are Healthline articles on [https://www.healthline.com/nutrition/coffee-worlds-biggest-source-of-antioxidants coffee antioxidants ("Many of coffee’s positive health effects may be due to its impressive content of powerful antioxidants")], [https://www.healthline.com/nutrition/black-tea-benefits#benefits anti-disease effects of black tea], [https://www.healthline.com/nutrition/ashwagandha "proven health benefits" of ashwagandha], and [https://www.healthline.com/nutrition/10-proven-benefits-of-blueberries "proven health benefits" of blueberries], among dozens of others. Search "antioxidant" on Healthline and browse any retrieved article for the extent of misinformation (where only vitamins A-C-E apply as antioxidants for the human diet).

Diffs on [[goji]]  - [[Talk:Goji#No_health_benefits?|this talk discussion on goji nutrition and health benefits]]; continued further [[Talk:Goji#Really?_there_needs_to_be_a_Nutrition_chapter|here]].

Numerous others under my history, [https://sigma.toolforge.org/summary.py?name=Zefr&search=healthline&server=enwiki&max=500&ns= here.]

It may be justified to blacklist Healthline as a perpetual source of fabrication and spam. Similar to reputations in scientific publishing generally, blatant misinformation destroys confidence permanently in the rest of the source. 

Seeing an edit containing a Healthline source is [[WP:REDFLAG]] for revising or reverting the edit. There are no circumstances where a Healthline source could not be MEDRS-sourced. 

Healthline should be blacklisted. [[User:Zefr|Zefr]] ([[User talk:Zefr|talk]]) 19:26, 28 May 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Good article nominations#rfc_F24078D|Wikipedia talk:Good article nominations]] expired 2023-06-28 11:01 ===
* Id: F24078D
* User: Mike_Christie
* Date: 2023-05-29 10:48:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/WikiProjects_and_collaborations|prev|1157552188|PROJ 1157552188}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/WikiProjects_and_collaborations|prev|1162324243|PROJ 1162324243}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I propose that criterion 2(b) of the [[WP:GACR|good article criteria]] should be changed from  
:{{tq|all [[Wikipedia:Inline citation|inline citations]] are from [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources|reliable sources]], including those for direct quotations, statistics, published opinion, counterintuitive or controversial statements that are challenged or [[Wikipedia:Likely to be challenged|likely to be challenged]], and contentious material relating to living persons—science-based articles should follow the [[Wikipedia:Scientific citation guidelines|scientific citation guidelines]]}}
to
:{{tq|[[WP:RS|reliable sources]] are [[Wikipedia:Citing sources#Inline citations|cited inline]]. All content, except for plot summaries and that which summarizes cited content elsewhere in the article, must be cited no later than the end of the paragraph (or line if the content is not in prose).}}

-- [[User:Mike Christie|Mike Christie]] ([[User_talk:Mike Christie|talk]] - [[Special:Contributions/Mike_Christie|contribs]] -  [[User:Mike Christie/Reference library|library]]) 10:48, 29 May 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:What Wikipedia is not#rfc_47315C7|Wikipedia talk:What Wikipedia is not]] expired 2023-06-29 04:01 ===
* Id: 47315C7
* Date: 2023-05-30 03:32:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1157660104|POLICY 1157660104}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1162432597|POLICY 1162432597}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should [[WP:NOTDIRECTORY]] be changed to the following?:
{{blockquote|[Wikipedia articles are not:] '''Simple listings''' without [[Wikipedia:Writing better articles#Provide context for the reader|contextual information]] showing encyclopedic merit. [[WP:DAB|Disambiguation pages]] (such as [[John Smith (disambiguation)|John Smith]]) are not intended to be complete listings of every person named John Smith—just the ones '''''as defined at [[MOS:DABMENTION]], or within the scope of [[Wikipedia:Disambiguation dos and don'ts|disambiguation]] or [[Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Disambiguation pages|style]] guidance.'''''}} ''Changes highlighted in bold and italica.''
03:32, 30 May 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Elections and Referendums#rfc_8700460|Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Elections and Referendums]] expired 2023-06-29 11:01 ===
* Id: 8700460
* Date: 2023-06-17 16:17:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1160606673|POL 1160606673}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1165823432|POL 1165823432}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should a consensus similar to the following be agreed to?:

: "Any result map included in an Electoral Infobox in an article about any election conducted on a '''statewide (e.g. Gubernatorial and Senate) '''or '''federal (i.e. Presidential)''' level in the United States of America and its territories must portray the election through either county (or relevant equivalent, i.e. parish) boundaries or precinct boundaries, except as follows:
:: - In the case of Presidential Election results in a state that employs a proportional method of distributing its electoral college votes by congressional district or other unit, a map in the Electoral Infobox may include the results broken down by the proportional method used, such as by congressional district or other method;
:: - In the case of the New England region and any other state with uniform Township/Municipality Boundaries, a map of a election result by Township/Municipality may be included in the electoral infobox if that was the method by which Election Results were reported by election officals;
:: - In cases where county boundaries are non-existent, such as with Alaska, a map of the next-best reporting unit may be used in the Electoral Infobox (In Alaska's case, borough/census area or state house districts); and
:: - In the case of Statewide elections that were dependent upon winning specified districts, such as Mississippi Row Office elections pre-2020, a map of election results by those boundaries may be included in the Electoral Infobox."[[User:Alexcs114| Alexcs114]] :) 16:17, 17 June 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:PragerU#rfc_8D58809|Talk:PragerU]] expired 2023-06-29 18:01 ===
* Id: 8D58809
* Date: 2023-05-30 17:28:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|1157746074|MEDIA 1157746074}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1157746077|POL 1157746077}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1157746078|SOC 1157746078}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|1168177154|MEDIA 1168177154}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1168177157|POL 1168177157}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1168177160|SOC 1168177160}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
At the time of this RfC, the article includes a sentence covering how PragerU profited off a video of theirs that contained anti-LGBT content.
There exists three sources for this content that have been discussed thus far, [https://www.mediamatters.org/dennis-prager/youtube-helping-prageru-fundraise-transphobia Media Matters], [https://www.washingtonblade.com/2021/01/07/5-things-social-media-platforms-can-do-to-combat-anti-lgbtq-disinformation Washington Blade], [https://www.cjr.org/the_media_today/congress-and-the-platforms-the-circus-is-back-in-town.php Columbia Journalism Review]. 

After intense debate above, it was work-shopped into three proposals:
'''Option A:''' {{tqb|PragerU raised more than $25,000 off of a video produced by anti-LGBT group [[Alliance Defending Freedom]]. The video featured [[anti-trans rhetoric]] and [[Misgender|misgendered]] trans competitors while arguing against the participation of [[Transgender people in sports|trans athletes]] in female sports.}}
'''Option B:''' {{tqb|PragerU raised more than $25,000 off of a video produced by anti-LGBTQ group [[Alliance Defending Freedom]]. The video, featuring a female high school athlete arguing against against [[Transgender people in sports|trans-athletes participating in female sports]], misgendered trans competitors by saying “biological boys who said they were transgender girls” and suggesting that they are not “actual girls.”}}
'''Option C:''' Leave it out entirely.

17:28, 30 May 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Sports/Handling sports transactions#rfc_D03C3CB|Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Sports/Handling sports transactions]] expired 2023-07-02 01:01 ===
* Id: D03C3CB
* User: The ed17
* Date: 2023-06-02 00:57:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1158106700|SOC 1158106700}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1162940688|SOC 1162940688}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Frequently, contracts between sports teams and players/coaches are leaked to media outlets before they are officially announced.

This essay is often invoked to keep any mention of these reported details out of articles until the signing is officially announced [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Monty_Williams&diff=prev&oldid=1158175674], and articles are protected to prevent new editors from adding the information. For examples: [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Doc_Rivers&oldid=1155093001] [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=D._J._Moore&oldid=1143971335]

This RfC is to determine if the following line should be altered:

{{quote|''If anything is to be presented at all, it should be limited to prose attributed to the source that is reporting the transaction.''}}

I would propose revising it to read like this:

{{quote|''Updates to articles subject to a reported transaction should be limited to prose that specifically [[WP:ATTRIBUTEPOV|attributes]] the source that is reporting the transaction.''}}

This change would codify and encourage Wikipedians old and new to cover what reliable sources will often widely report, but in a non-crystally way that communicates the uncertainty. An example of how that could look is in [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Monty_Williams&oldid=1158044193 Monty Williams' article]. [[User:The ed17|Ed]]&nbsp;<sup>[[User talk:The ed17|[talk]]]&nbsp;[[WP:OMT|[majestic titan]]]</sup> 00:57, 2 June 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Template talk:Infobox person#rfc_881A783|Template talk:Infobox person]] expired 2023-07-02 02:01 ===
* Id: 881A783
* User: Nikkimaria#David Bowie]]'''. Should template documentation be changed? Or some other clarification be sought? How say you all? &ndash;&nbsp;[[User:.Raven
* Date: 2023-06-02 01:23:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1158165939|BIO 1158165939}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1162947068|BIO 1162947068}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
How narrowly to read 'city' of birth/death?{{pb}}The infoboxes of [[Pearl Mackie]], [[Peter Hawkins]], [[Danny Kirwan]], and [[Tony Sewell, Baron Sewell of Sanderstead]] read "Born... [[Brixton]], London, England". For a short while, so did the infobox for [[David Bowie]]; then "Brixton" was removed from that last infobox, on the grounds that only a "city" should be named, and Brixton is not a city (though it has a larger population than 17 of the USA's state capitals, and in-real-life form fields marked "city" are routinely filled in with names of other place-types – town, village, etc. – where appropriate).  How narrowly should that word "city" be read? This has been discussed by {{ping|Bretonbanquet|Nikkimaria}} and me, at '''[[User talk:Nikkimaria#David Bowie]]'''. Should template documentation be changed? Or some other clarification be sought? How say you all? &ndash;&nbsp;[[User:.Raven|<big>'''.'''</big>Raven]]&nbsp;<sup>[[User talk:.Raven|&nbsp;'''''.'''talk'']]</sup> 01:23, 2 June 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Durham special counsel investigation#rfc_FD5BEF7|Talk:Durham special counsel investigation]] expired 2023-07-02 16:01 ===
* Id: FD5BEF7
* User: Soibangla
* Date: 2023-06-02 15:47:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1158205666|HIST 1158205666}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1158205669|POL 1158205669}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1163039739|HIST 1163039739}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1163039745|POL 1163039745}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the current lead sentence...

{{tq2|The report concluded the FBI had showed confirmation bias and a "serious lack of analytical rigor" toward the information they received, especially information the FBI received from politically affiliated persons and entities.}}

be amended to include this bold content...

{{tq2|The report concluded the FBI had showed confirmation bias and a "serious lack of analytical rigor" toward the information they received, especially information the FBI received from politically affiliated persons and entities. '''Durham asserted this information "in part triggered" the Crossfire Hurricane investigation, echoing a <s>disproved</s> conspiracy theory promoted by Trump supporters.'''}}

This question is rooted in what [[Charlie Savage (author)|Charlie Savage]] exclusively reported in ''The New York Times'':

{{tq2|Mr. Durham went beyond criticizing the wiretap applications, writing: "Our investigation also revealed that senior F.B.I. personnel displayed a serious lack of analytical rigor toward the information that they received, especially information received from politically affiliated persons and entities. This information in part triggered and sustained Crossfire Hurricane and contributed to the subsequent need for Special Counsel Mueller’s investigation."}}

{{tq2|But in using the word "triggered," Mr. Durham’s report echoed a conspiracy theory pushed by supporters of Mr. Trump that the F.B.I. opened the investigation in July 2016 based on the so-called Steele dossier, opposition research indirectly funded by the Clinton campaign that was later discredited.[https://www.nytimes.com/2023/05/15/us/politics/trump-russia-investigation-durham.html]}}

<s>The NYT does not use the word "disproved" but that can be readily sourced if this edit is ultimately adopted.</s>

This matter has been previously discussed in [[Talk:Durham special counsel investigation#our article vs NYT reporting|this Talk thread]]. [[User:Soibangla|soibangla]] ([[User talk:Soibangla|talk]]) 15:47, 2 June 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:CheckUser#rfc_8EB2610|Wikipedia talk:CheckUser]] expired 2023-07-07 15:01 ===
* Id: 8EB2610
* User: Shim119
* Date: 2023-07-07 13:52:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1163997947|POLICY 1163997947}}

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Many years ago, the arbcom reminded users that checkusers have access to hidden information most of us don't.  while it's accepted that undoing an arbcom decision lead to desysopping arbcom editors are usually held in an official light given they're nominated by a more rigorous process than the run of the mill RFA where all editor can simply support or oppose the request.  That being said I would like to clarify
#are checkusers a subdivision of arbcom?
#given that a checkuser block can be restore like any other edit, would it be more prudent to AGF on the part person who reversed the block and simply restore the block?  hundreds of accounts get indeffed and all too often the creator of these accounts end up in a vicious cycle of sock/block they can't escape.  
#how exactly would regular admin unblocking a checkuserblock undermine the site's integrity?  [[User:Shim119|Shim119]] ([[User talk:Shim119|talk]]) 13:52, 7 July 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Capital letters#rfc_59719F7|Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Capital letters]] expired 2023-07-08 10:01 ===
* Id: 59719F7
* User: .Raven
* Date: 2023-07-07 19:01:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1164065650|POL 1164065650}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1164065656|SOC 1164065656}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|1164065660|STYLE 1164065660}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1164210331|POL 1164210331}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1164210333|SOC 1164210333}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|1164210336|STYLE 1164210336}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
 -->
Should the capitalization of titles for specific nations' armed forces members follow their own nations' practices, e.g. "Spanish marine" but "[U.S.] Marine" and (U.K.) "Royal Marine" for individuals? For instance:
* [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2023/01/23/afghan-asylum-seeker-murdered-aspiring-royal-marine/ "An Afghan double killer was able to sneak into Britain posing as a 14-year-old schoolboy before going on to murder an aspiring Royal Marine, it has emerged."]
* [https://www.defense.gov/Multimedia/Photos/igphoto/2001718628/ "A Spanish marine, left, explains how her weapon works to a U.S. Marine...."]
This presumes the terms not attached to any specific nation remain uncapitalized, e.g. [[List of marines and naval infantry forces|"Many countries around the world maintain marines and naval infantry military units."]]
{{hab}}  &ndash;&nbsp;[[User:.Raven|<big>'''.'''</big>Raven]]&nbsp;<small>[[User talk:.Raven|&nbsp;'''''.'''talk'']]</small> 19:01, 7 July 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:JoJo (singer)#rfc_DF04D5B|Talk:JoJo (singer)]] expired 2023-07-09 17:01 ===
* Id: DF04D5B
* User: Breaktheicees
* Date: 2023-06-27 04:02:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|1164428511|MEDIA 1164428511}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|1164529040|MEDIA 1164529040}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
While many sources refer to this release (''Trying Not to Think About It'') as an EP, as does JoJo herself, it doesn't appear to fit the definition of one on the [[extended play]] page. Both its length time-wise (33 minutes) and its number of songs (12, or 8 if you discount the intro and interludes) are more befitting of a full-length [[album]]. Should we thus leave it labeled as is, per JoJo's categorization, or instead label it as what other projects of this scope and length would typically be labeled as? [[User:Breaktheicees|Breaktheicees]] ([[User talk:Breaktheicees|talk]]) 04:02, 27 June 2023 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard#rfc_315AD7E|Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard]] expired 2023-07-09 20:01 ===
